title: Wispr Flow | Write 4x Faster with AI Speech-to-Text That Works Everywhere
text:
Get Started: https://ref.wisprflow.ai/go

Tired of typing? Meet Wispr Flow ‚Äî the voice-to-text app that lets you write four times faster in every app, on any device. Whether you‚Äôre writing emails, coding, taking notes, or chatting, Flow turns your speech into clean, perfectly formatted text ‚Äî instantly.

Wispr Flow is my tool of choice for fast, polished voice-to-text in any app.

üöÄ Why people love Wispr Flow:
‚Ä¢ Works in every app ‚Äî on Mac, Windows, and iPhone
‚Ä¢ 4√ó faster than typing
‚Ä¢ AI Auto Edits remove filler words and fix grammar
‚Ä¢ Learns your unique words with a personal dictionary
‚Ä¢ Automatically adjusts tone by app (email, chat, docs, code)
‚Ä¢ Supports 100+ languages

No setup. No clunky dictation. Just talk ‚Äî and Flow writes exactly what you mean.

üéØ Perfect for:
Writers ‚Ä¢ Developers ‚Ä¢ Founders ‚Ä¢ Students ‚Ä¢ Anyone who wants to save time and think out loud

üëá Try Wispr Flow now:
üåê https://wisprflow.ai

üì± Works on: iPhone | Mac | Windows

subtitles.srt: You've been typing your whole life and it's slowing you down. What if you could write four times faster in every app on any device just by talking? For over 150 years, we've been stuck behind a keyboard, typing, correcting, making the thoughts fit the fingers. But what if you could just talk and have your words appear clean, formatted, ready? That's right. Up to four times faster than typing when you speak your thoughts instead of typing them. Meet Whisper Flow, the voicetoext tool that works in every app on your iPhone, Mac, or Windows computer. Speak naturally at the speed you think and let Flow handle the rest. Whether you're coding, emailing, writing reports, chatting, or capturing ideas, Flow is there. Feature number one, AI autoedits. You simply speak. No need to stop and correct. Rambling thoughts become clear, perfectly formatted text without filler words or typos. Flow listens, it cleans, it delivers your words like you intended. Feature number two, personal dictionary. Flow learns your unique words, names, industry jargon, custom terms, and adds them automatically. No more repeated corrections. Flow remembers so you don't have to. Feature number three, different tones for each app. Flow automatically adjusts your tone depending on which app you're in, so you still sound like you, not a robot. Whether you're writing formal business email or friendly chat, Flow adapts. Feature number four, 100 plus languages. Flow autodetects your language and transcribes it so you can move between them just like you do. Multilingual, no problem. Flow keeps up. In short, you get up to fourplex faster writing than typing. Clean, polished text thanks to AI autoedits. Your own personal dictionary so Flow gets your style. Tone adaptation across apps. You always sound like you. Full multilingual support, 100 plus languages. Works across devices, Mac, Windows, iPhone. Stop waiting for your fingers to keep up. Speak at the speed you think. Let Flow do the heavy lifting. Then use the time you save to create, to connect, to live. The keyboard era isn't bad. It's just time to move past it. To get started, click on the link in the description below.

title: AI Dictation: It's About YOU, Not The App. A Look at Wispr Flow, Superwhisper, VoiceInk & Spokenly
text:
In this video I walk you through how I use AI dictation day to day on Mac and why the ‚Äúbest app‚Äù depends more on you than the tool. You‚Äôll see Wispr Flow and Superwhisper side by side for speed, accuracy, and intelligent cleanup, then we push into commands, tone changes, and context awareness. I also show you where Spokenly and Voice Ink fit‚Äîespecially around local vs cloud models, API keys, and privacy‚Äîand why some features matter more than flashy demos. If you care about simple dictation I'll cover Wispr Flow, Willow Voice, Aqua Voice, and Ito AI; if you want control, I'll talk about why Superwhisper, Voice Ink, and Spokenly open up deeper workflows.

From there, I'll get specific into the features that matter to me as a power user. I will cover Superwhisper context awareness features and overall app interaction compared to VoiceInk and Spokenly. I also tell you some strengths of VoiceInk and Spokenly over Superwhisper and when it's worth it paying the price difference (for unlimited processing with models like OpenAI, Anthropic). 

Bottom line: pick the lane that matches your brain. If you want no-fuss dictation, Wispr Flow, Willow Voice, or Aqua Voice, Ito AI get you there fast. If you want to shape the tool to your workflow‚Äîwith custom prompts, model choice , and advanced context‚ÄîSuperwhisper is still my pick, with Voice Ink and Spokenly as solid options depending on your needs.s.

subtitles.srt: Hey guys, my name is Robert. A bit over a year ago, I made a video giving an overview of some of the most popular options available for AI dictation on Mac. I want to share my thoughts on the current state of this topic and take a look at some popular and not so popular options. I do not believe there is a single app which is the best of all. In my opinion, there is a certain standard that needs to be reached for a dictation app to be considered solid, but above that standard, everything else is a matter of little details in the workflow or implementation of features. I want to explain this with two of the apps I just showed you. First, we got Whisperflow. This app is built for simplicity. The whole idea is making AI dictation so easy that anyone can use it to replace typing. You get some customization options, keyboard shortcuts, dictionary words, replacements, but this app is minimal on purpose. It just has the absolute essentials when it comes to settings. They are aiming for the widest market possible, so everything stays pretty straightforward. At the same time, everything is a bit of a mystery. It truly feels magical if you jump to this for the first time without having checked out any of the other alternatives, because you don't know what's going on. I do have to say something important here. A bit over a year ago, when Whisperflow was pretty new, there were a lot of questions and complaints about privacy regarding this app. What kind of data was being captured? How was it being used? At that time, the team was not clear about this as well, and their privacy policy was a confusing mess. Recently, however, I have noticed they have been proactively improving in this area. And look, none of the existing apps is perfect. What matters to me is that right now, at least, it seems like the team at Whisperflow is listening. They are trying to communicate more, and I can see the improvements. The app now has more settings that allow opt-out for data retention or training, and you can also turn off context awareness if you prefer. They have also obtained certifications that ensure privacy for health professionals or corporations. All of this to say that, even though I still find a lot of their marketing strategy too spammy, pushy, and I do not agree that AI dictation will or should replace old typing, I think that as a product that aims for the most user-friendliness, it's very solid. On the other side of the spectrum, you have Super Whisper. This app is a big contrast. It's built for control, transparency, and power. Instead of hiding things, it actually shows you everything that is being captured and sent. It lets you run with local models or cloud models, which allow for a higher degree of privacy if you care about that. You can toggle on and off a lot of options that will personalize your interactions with the app and the results that you get, which means you also have an incredible amount of flexibility. With custom modes where you are in full control of the instructions sent to AI and with unlimited usage of AI included for the latest OpenAI or cloud models, Super Whisper can be used for more than simple dictation. It can truly be a powerful AI assistant that you can deeply integrate into more advanced workflows. In short, this app puts the user in control, letting you customize things to an impressive degree. That's the fundamental difference. I must say that I still think simplicity is a characteristic of good app design. I am not against this. It's just that apps that follow the line of Whisperflow put user-friendliness at the very core of everything and sacrifice some customization to achieve it. Apps that follow the line of Super Whisper start from a different place. They build for power and flexibility first, then they try to make that complexity manageable. Both approaches are valid, it just depends on what you value more. Having things work without any tweaking right out of the box, or having the freedom to shape the tool around your own particular workflow. So when you are looking at all of these AI dictation tools I will mention, the first thing is to figure out what kind of user you actually are. This is more important than you may think, and it can save you lots of time and frustrations down the road. So what do we have in the first group? Whisper Flow is the most popular in this category, but there are other good alternatives. Willow Voice keeps the same minimal approach, and what sets it apart is that it learns from your corrections. And all of that can optionally show up right in this floating panel if you have it active. It's actually pretty cool, put that in parenthesis. It's just a bit slower when used like this. It also uses Avalon, their own transcription model that claims to be more accurate with technical terms. AquaVoice also lets you enter custom instructions that apply based on which app you are using. It feels like this app is stepping a little bit into advanced territory because of the features it has. On the other hand, Aqua does not currently have a command mode that you can find in both Whisperflow and WillowVoice. This is what allows you to do stuff like, hey, write me an outline for one article on AI dictation. Now, an important thing to consider is that Whisperflow, AquaVoice, and WillowVoice, they are all subscription-based, and it makes sense because they use cloud models for transcription and processing. This is what allows them to perform with the speed and accuracy they need. Actually, a lot of what they do behind the scenes, like I was saying before, it's still quite a bit of a mystery, so there's not a lot of information out there about how processing happens, what specifically is being captured, and how. This means that when it comes to privacy or handling of data, you basically just have to trust them. Because of that, I was happy to find an open-source alternative that takes a similar approach but with way more transparency. It's called E2AI. Right now, the app is in a very early stage. It only does basic clean-up and has a command mode, but it's getting better fast and it should catch up to the others soon. The main thing here is that, since E2AI is open-source, you can see exactly what's happening under the hood. Currently, it's free and there's instructions available so you can even build it yourself. Now, let's switch to the other group. I have been using Super Whisper for over a year and I should probably admit upfront that I am a bit biased here. My whole setup already depends on it so it's tough for me to be completely neutral. It's not perfect though. I actually have specific frustrations and that's what has made me look around at other options. I'll get into those later. But for now, I want to focus on what matters to me as someone who needs more control and customization. For users new to this, maybe apps like Spokenly or Voicing that I will cover in this section could be enough, but I'm looking at this from a different angle. I am testing this against what I already know that worked for me, so I am using SuperWhisper as a standard here. First, let's talk about context awareness. This for me is one of the most important advanced features. It's about the app knowing not just what you are saying, but also receiving information about what you are working on and providing that to AI so you can get better results. Whisper is very strong here and it handles context capture in a very sophisticated way. It captures three main types of context: selective text, application context, and clipboard context. The amazing part here is that it captures this at different specific timings. I have a video that explains all of this in detail, but in summary, this allows you to craft pretty complex requests. For example, let's say: Hey, I need you to grab my selected text and give it the same kind of formatting you find in my application context. After testing with voice ink, I was surprised to find that there is a bit of a difference with timing, but it can actually do the same. Hey, I needed to grab my selected text and give it the same format you find in my application context. With voice ink, I have to end my dictation where I have my selected text, which feels a little bit strange because the result is gone and it's only on my clipboard. It's okay. I just have to paste and the result is about the same. One thing I personally don't like is how voice ink deals with clipboard context. It will always include it, whereas in Super Whisper, I am in control of whether I want to copy something or not during dictation. That's just a minor detail. Something that is more important to me is that application context in Super Whisper is more powerful for many of my use cases, which have to do with grinding and developing content. Both voicing and spokenly will only capture a screenshot of your current app window, but Super Whisper will capture all the content that you have in your active input field. What do I mean by this? Okay, let me show you. Hey, tell me the name of the person in the first sentence. See, it grabbed my name, and above is actually part of the script of the video you are watching now, and there is my name on the first sentence. I need to structure my thoughts better." By the way, guess what? I know that for some users, downloading an application like this from the App Store will give them a lot of peace of mind, but when it comes to context capture, this is also the reason it's very limited, but it can do one thing very well: it gives the user absolute control over the system prompt. This is another aspect that really matters to me. Unfortunately, the context limitations I mentioned earlier because of the App Store sandboxing hold it back. In Voicing, when you edit a prompt, you have a toggle that will define if you want your instructions to be attached to the main dictation prompt or if you want total control. I really like this approach. It's very simple and I think that it avoids a lot of confusion that I see from users in Super Whisper. Super Whisper takes a different approach. This is meant to make the app more user-friendly for people who don't like to mess with custom instructions. But you can also build custom modes from scratch, which is what I do for the most part. Something that users have to know is that, unlike spokenly or voicing, where you have the ability to use your instructions attached to the original dictation system prompt, here we do not have that yet. Let me show you what that means in action. In spokenly, I go to my custom instructions and add it. Always output the dictation in a very professional tone. Now let me dictate with this, and it shows up with something. The result is transformed as expected, but let's try the same with Super Whisper. I create a custom mode, and I add the exact same instructions. Now I will switch to that mode, and I will dictate, and it shows up with something. What's happening here? The application is working as intended, it's just that the AI model doesn't know that I'm trying to get this text transformed into something else. In spokenly, I would get a similar result if I go into Advanced Settings and change the actual system prompt. This is what trips some users off, because yes, you have an amazing amount of flexibility, and honestly, with the behavior of context captured, like I showed you, plus this flexibility with prompting, I think Super Whisper does give you more power at this point of time than any of the other apps. By setting your custom instructions correctly, you can also imitate some of the behavior of the apps in the first group, as I was showing you in the beginning. But if you don't know how this works, you can also end up very frustrated because you may dictate something that sounds like a request, and the AI will try to answer you, or you will not be getting the results that you expect. With Spokenly, you need to have more than one AI prompt for this option to appear. In VoiceInc, you set this when you are creating a new power mode, and in Super Whisperer, you also got that under each mode settings. Let's say you want a specific rule for a specific tone formatting when you are dictating in Slack, or you have a different way of communicating in WhatsApp. Maybe you always want dictations formatted as emails in your mail app. You can set up stuff like that. I normally do not use this feature because in the same app that I use for note-taking, I write emails, I write outlines, I summarize stuff, so I prefer switching manually when I have to. I like to be in absolute control. In Spokenly, you can set keyboard shortcuts for each separate AI prompt, but here's the problem that I have with that. Dictation should empower your flow state. By that, I mean that it should be as non-disruptive as possible. If I'm about to start dictating, I don't want to think. What's the shortcut for writing emails? What's the shortcut for outlining an article? So, I do have a personal issue with the way that Spokenly does it. Voicing improves this with the ability to set one keyboard shortcut to always start or stop dictation. Once you start, you switch with modifiers plus numbers. I really like that it's the same one action to start or stop dictating. I also like that if you don't set a default power mode, your choice stays active. This means that whatever mode you used the last time will stay for the next time. But switching with modifiers and numbers feels very awkward to me. You also have a very confusing separation between AI enhancements and power modes. On the other hand, in this app, you have something cool, which is trigger words. This means you can start dictating with a specific word and your text will be automatically processed by the AI prompt you have associated with that, but you run into the same issue as keyboard shortcuts that I was telling you with spokenly, having to decide what word you will have to say the exact same moment you are about to start dictating. This breaks a lot of my concentration and flow. So, we have many different options to set this up, but the overall functionality design could be much better. I think that Super Whisper made a genius decision by setting mode switching as separate from dictation. It's two separate processes. But this means that you can switch modes with Alfred, Raycast, or stuff like Better Touch Tool, Keyboard Maestro, and more. The reason this is very important for me as someone who cares about focus and productivity is that every time my brain decides to start working on something, my fingers already did the change. Not when I'm about to start talking in the microphone, but the moment of making that internal switch, my creative side connects with my hands. It's super intuitive and I haven't found that anywhere else. This also gives me some more advanced flexibility in my workflow because this means that I can dictate one time and test that recording through different modes. When I'm using AI directly in something like ChatGPT or Altar, I use this without any extra processing because it's the fastest. It is messy, but AI has no trouble understanding me. But with Super Whisperer, once I dictate it, I can switch modes with one key press. If I start a new dictation right now, it will be cleaned up, but I can also reprocess what I just dictated. Okay, we've got a cleaned up version, but say that I want to run it through another prompt to translate it into Spanish. I just do the switch, and I run the same audio through it. With other apps, you have to open the application, go to the history panel, and choose how you want to reprocess a specific dictation. Having this at your fingertips is an incredible time saver. So when it comes to the main interaction with the app, which is mode switching, for me, Super Whisper wins here. Now, I want to briefly touch on one more aspect that matters to power users, AI models. There's two sides to this, transcription models and LLM processing. When it comes to transcription models, both spokenly and voicing offer way more options than Super Whisper. Let me tell you that technology in this field is moving incredibly fast, and I expect we will eventually reach a point where all models are fast, smart, and accurate across multiple languages. We are getting close, but we are not there yet. Right now, different models are good at different things. Some transcribe better in certain languages, and some prioritize speed over accuracy. Throughout this video, I have been using Super Whisper's S1 voice model for transcription. It's a cloud model based on Whisper that's incredibly fast, almost instant for quick dictation. If you are on voicing or spokenly, you've got a local model called Parakeet, which is also crazy fast, but the accuracy is worse. I would say, for people who are okay with Whisper models and their language support, or who are fine with Nova models, which, by the way, include real-time transcription and speaker separation, then you will be fine with Super Whisper. But the truth is, there's constant competition with new models coming out all the time, and this app does not incorporate them as quickly as voicing or spokenly. This area that has to do with AI models also plays a role with the pricing of each app. Voicing is a one-time payment at $25. It doesn't include cloud models usage in this pricing. You pay for that with your own API keys. After purchase, you could also use it with local models at no cost, of course. Spokenly can be used totally for free in this same way, with local models and with your own API keys. The difference here is that you don't have to pay anything if you go this route. This app will only require a subscription payment if you wanted to manage the access to all the AI being used. That way you don't need to deal with API keys and stuff like that. Finally, SuperWhisper offers both a subscription and a one-time payment option at $250, which sounds like a crazy difference compared to the other two, but here's the thing. SuperWhisper is the only option in AI dictation that provides true unlimited access to the latest models from OpenAI and Anthropic for processing your dictation or transcribed audio files. That can be a massive advantage. So I'll say that right now, SuperWhisper is my personal top choice because of the combination of features that I have talked about. There's a lot more I haven't covered, like all the automation possibilities if you get MacroWhisper that I built for this. I got other videos on that topic. Something to consider is that even if Voice Inc. eventually matches SuperWhisper's features for app context and makes the interaction more intuitive, or if spokenly, leaves the app store and becomes more powerful, I really doubt they will ever offer unlimited AI processing at a one-time payment the way SuperWhisper does. For many users who know what unlimited SONE or unlimited CHGPT means, this starts to sound too good to be true. And it is. But here's another important thing. Most people don't actually need these premium models in a dictation app. Throughout this video for LLM processing, I have been using a model called Kimi K2 through Grok, which is totally free because it's open source. For quick dictation tasks, I don't generally go for open AI or anthropic models at all because, yes, they are smarter, but slower. The unlimited AI processing becomes most useful when you combine it with SuperWhisper's other features and start to use it as an assistant or for more complex tasks. It's also great if you are processing longer dictations and don't mind sacrificing some speed for better results. Finding this app has been quite life-changing for my learning of AI and it has revolutionized how I use my computer, but if you are just planning to do quick dictations and format emails or bullet lists, maybe, just maybe you'll be fine with something else. As I start to grab up this video, I want to give you a quick summary or rather a guide to help you figure out what right for you. If you are still watching this far, but feel like all you need is simplicity and user friendliness above anything else, then go with apps in that first group. Go with AquaVoice if you need some customization with instructions. WillowVoice may be a great alternative if you want some of that personalization in terms of writing style, but you want it to happen automatically. I would say WhisperFlow also is a very solid choice, especially now that they have fixed a lot of the communication or privacy issues that I saw in the past. I also really like the context awareness that's available for command mode in WhisperFlow. You can do powerful stuff with that. Any of these apps will work well if you want something super straightforward and don't mind the subscription tag. There's also the open source Ito AI that I mentioned. It might be enough for you. At this point, it's very basic, but it's free and it will give you fast dictation with a general cleanup. The main limitation here is that it doesn't have as many extra tricks compared to the other apps yet, but I think you will get there soon. Another option for users that are okay with something simple is Alter. This app is primarily a very powerful AI assistant and you can get access to its voice features for $29 a year. I would say that the dictation itself is more basic than anything I have mentioned so far, but if you are interested in the assistant capabilities or need transcription with speaker separation, then the dictation becomes a nice little extra. I have covered more about Alter in a few other videos if you want to learn more about it. If you want to put in a little bit more effort and level up from the basic options, I think Spokenly would be a good entry-level app for this category. If you want to use your own API keys and local models, you can use it for free. If you pay for it, you don't have to deal with any of that. This app actually does have some more advanced features that I didn't mention in this video, like the triggering of scripts, which allows for some automation and you can set more parameters for the LLMs. It's just that for me, it always hits those sandboxing limits. If this app eventually implements AppContext correctly or comes up with a version outside of the App Store, it could truly expand its capabilities and jump to the next level. But I'm not sure if we will ever see that happen. For now, though, I think it's the best middle ground. For power users who love to customize, Voice Ink is solid, but it's not my personal top pick right now. The workflow choices with the interface feel awkward, the separation between enhancements and power modes is confusing, and design-wise, it just doesn't feel well thought out. There are too many small friction points that add up, things that make you pause or second-guess yourself when you should be focused on your work. At this point, I would find it very difficult to switch. If you haven't used Super Whisper, maybe it's good enough for you, especially if you don't need the unlimited AI models that Super Whisper offers. Super Whisper continues to be my recommendation for users who care about personalizing their workflow. The unlimited AI side definitely sets it apart, but it's all the other details in the implementation of features that actually allow you to take advantage of that power, and it can expand into so many different areas. If you care about productivity, automation around your system by voice, you are into deep work, or if you are interested in exploring the possibilities of AI across anything that has to do with voice or text, I still think that there's nothing that has reached this level yet. Let me be real with you about something. Part of the reason I have been testing all these other apps is because Super Whisper went through some changes that really frustrated me. The settings panel got redesigned a few months back and it made everything harder to navigate. Some things that I have always considered little secret features have ended up being non-intentional and removed. Plus, now there are these notifications that show up every time you switch modes. I hate them so much and find them really distracting when I'm trying to focus. See, I don't mind changes, but I think that they should not affect the overall workflow that people are already used to. If changes will be implemented, then there should be the option to preserve the previous behavior and stuff like this. Sometimes I get the impression that this app is caught between being a power tool and trying to compete with simpler options like Whisperflow. I don't think that should happen. They are very different markets. What's unfortunate is that because of this identity crisis, it seems like Super Whisper sometimes struggles with giving users more settings and control. That's a shame because power and flexibility are its biggest strengths. Super Whisper is also a small team working on Windows and iOS versions at the same time. So the focus and communication with users could be much better. That said, I have seen several improvements lately. There's been fixes to the interface. The app feels more stable. I have talked with Neil, the developer, a few times, and I feel like he is listening more. The last few months have definitely been bumpy, but I still believe where this is headed. After spending time looking at other alternatives and seeing how they do things, I can definitely see how Super Whisperer is not the best option for everyone, and I hope that everything I have shared here can help you figure this out for yourself. As for me, I'm happy with this app and hope to continue making more content about how I use it in the future. I just really need those stupid notifications gone. Please. Thank you so much for watching guys. If this video was useful to you and you decide to try Super Whisper, I hope you all consider using my affiliate link. It would support me in making more content like this. Remember, you can always sign up to my newsletter for more updates on what I'm up to. I'll see you in the next one.

They also have a feature called dictionary¬† where it's going to learn about you over time. So for example, in this case, you can add new words¬† and be able to share them with your team as well so that they can have correlated words. So if you¬† work in a company where jargon is very particular, then this might be something to be help set¬† things up. Now you can create your own notes in this area, which is a helpful feature, but largely¬† all the activity runs through the center here. So, you're probably wondering, how is this¬† even useful? How is this beneficial? Well, they've got a mobile app which will help you to¬† take the meeting notes through there. So, if you want to do a one-on-one person, that's going to be¬† helpful, but it also will help you to do your own personal notes as well. And you can also use this¬† desktop pretty much for whatever you want. So, if you're somebody that likes to ask clawed¬† questions while you're coding and you don't want to move your hands from the mouse or write¬† them out, then that's something you can do because you just have to hit that function button and it¬† jumps straight in. I have been starting to play with these type of apps in particular for email.¬† The reason being is because when I'm writing email and I'm in the office in a closed environment, I'm¬† just talking the email because it's so much easier and it normally gets the tone. It normally gets¬† the attributes and it just does it faster. If I was in a coffee shop, I probably wouldn't do¬† that. But at the same time, I find it's more humanlike if I'm starting to talk it out loud¬† as well. Sometimes it adds in tones like that's amazing or that's fantastic that I have said,¬† but it just dictates it more accurately. So, there are some pricing plans. So, you do get a¬† limit on the free plan. It's 2,000 words a week, which can be a limit for many people. And you¬† can add words to your dictionary as well as all of the abilities I've showed you here. The premium¬† pricing is $12 per month. That's unlimited words. And command mode editing as well. So, command¬† mode allows you to go in and edit stuff to be more accurate. So, if there's a section of text¬† that you want to improve, I do this all the time inside of email, then you can do that as well. And¬† you can also see unlimited mobile use, too. So, $12. Again, if you're aggressively using this,¬† is probably a considered bet for you. You can also change what your keyboard commands are as¬† well. So, if you want to do hands-free mode, you can do that. And that's just something you can¬† play with. So, Whisper Flow is an interesting app. If you're somebody that spends a lot of time¬† doing and managing email and you're good with your voice, for example, you like to just talk¬† sometimes versus actually do it. it's probably me, then these type of apps will be good for you.¬† There are a range of them, so I'll include as many as I can below. However, Whisper Flow. I like¬† how they set up with the function button. That's quite nice. The app was fluid to use in my tests.¬† And also, I quite like the statistical scores just cuz you're able to see, okay, words per minute.¬† Am I beating what score? Maybe it's just to give you an idea of how effective you are. So, I¬† think this is a good app worth checking out. and they're growing as a company apparently. I've been¬† keeping an eye on them as a startup like I do with many of them. But check them out in the link in¬† description if you're interested. And of course, Bento Focus too. Thanks very much and I'll¬† see you all very soon. Cheerio for now.

subtitles.srt: All right, everyone. I'm really excited today. It's the first of a series of new interviews that coming back to our YouTube channel and I started with a tool that I really love and in fact the CEO of the tool, Tana Kotari, here he is. >> Thanks for having me, man. Well, I'm pumped to go into this because uh whisper flow for those who don't know what this tool is, it is actually well people would call it dictation tool which I think is not giving it justification. It is doing much more than that. And I discovered whisperflow while I was doing coding and I started using whisper flow but our community and our audience are busy professionals. And that's where I very quickly realized man this is really saving time. Our co-founder Paco Cano he will never use an audio transcription tool because he's such a fast writer and he needs to think while he's writing. And I think that's something we need to discuss today. >> Who is really the target audience and who is it for? For me, it's I rather want to talk into my tool and then refine afterwards. So, I get my thoughts out there. Well, it's different types of thinking and as we do at the paperless movement, we talk about the difference between deep thinking and shallow thinking and especially when I do quick notes like or prompting. I use a lot whisper flow and it does so much more than other audio transcription tools. And before we dive in and then you can fire ahead, I just want to share the story here that I just today received a comment on YouTube below my whisper flow video where I showed the people how it works. Does it actually work with Thunderbird, my email provider, right? >> Or email app that I'm using. And I just responded, well, it doesn't matter what tool you use. As soon there is a text box, you can use it. And that's what makes it so versatile and easy to use. So Tanai, cannot wait to dive in. Maybe you introduce yourself and a bit more of the background and the story and why you ended up with Whisper Flow and then we go into the nitty-gritty, I'd say. >> Sure. Happy to dive in. So hey everyone, I'm T. I'm the CEO and co-founder of Whisperflow. And we've been working on Whisper Flow for the last one and a half years. But for me, it's been something that I've been working on for the last 18 years, which is what is the next generation of personal computing really look like? Cuz back in 2008, when the first Iron Man movie came out, I wanted to build Jarvis. And me and a friend of mine built what was then one of the world's first voice assistants. This is before Siri, before Alexa, to people just felt like magic. It grew to a few million users in the first few months. Then Google actually shut us down with a cease and desist. And while that company died, the thing that stayed with me was every time I saw somebody on their phone or their computer, it just felt so effortful and so mechanical and not how I want technology to feel like at all. For me, it's something that should just feel seamless. It just gets you. It's with you 24/7 and instead of drawing you into screens, it just lets you be a lot more present. And so today as we build whisper flow the key thing I think about and and this goes to some of the things you mentioned earlier as as well Tom is what I want is when I when I look at somebody's day spending 8 hours in their day I want to take every part of it that feels like grunt work and I want to make that experience better. I want to save time for people. I want to reduce that work off of their plate. Build AI that doesn't replace but augments humans. And so at the end, what you have is just more time for things that you really want to do, things that give you joy, things where you feel you're doing deep work. And the grunt work is what I want to replace. So to your your co-founder's point, Tom, if that's something he enjoys doing, he loves thinking while writing, I don't want to take that away. But for a lot of people, if you know what you want to say, you wake up in the morning, you have 50 emails in your inbox, you pretty much know what you want to respond to them. Why take two hours doing that when you can do it in 20 minutes with whisper? >> And that is where we see the largest amount of usage happen is people who are just burnt out and overwhelmed with the number of messages they have. Another group of people who love using it is a lot of developers and people who are starting to use AI tools a lot more to give themselves superpowers, do a lot more work faster to prompt them. Cuz again, the more context you give these tools, the better they work. And you just don't want to type all of that out. But when you're speaking, you just can go on a two-minute ramble, have a nice detailed prompt ready for you, just press enter, and it gets the work done for you. So hopefully that's helpful context setting and Tom happy to dive into whatever else of mind. >> Thanks so much and uh I like the ambitions behind this and well you're not alone in this world with making the life better and as so many productivity tools that we worked with in the past are promising too. The thing is really that the issue that we see over and over, it's really hard for them to understand what the people actually need and it gets worse the more people are using the tool because then everybody has an opinion. They think they might need this feature in the tool >> and then it becomes like the flag in the wind and and it becomes nothing. I'm not mentioning any tools out there but maybe some people can make a about this. But before we dive into this um I just want to mention I see a connection there with handwriting note-taking app evolution or revolution what you want to call it. So when I launched the channel in in 2018 I was talking a lot about handwriting note-taking apps and it's obvious why this became so popular. People love handwriting. Not everybody. Again, my co-founder never tries to handwrite. He always types, right? But so many people are better in thinking using a handwriting note-taking app or actually piece of paper and write something out. That's why we have tools like remarkable and things like that that people think they can use for their advantage. And back then it was easy to sell because telling people that people can now search through their handwriting and find information faster than going through the different paper notebooks. at the same time having it secured in the cloud this was revolutionary and the moment people understood this this became a real thing and Apple was the one who made it perfect again. So with whisper flow I see this the same way there was a lot of dictation things it it barely gets it right when you use the native uh dictation tools on the iPhone and so on. we got more and more this that it actually works to talk to the tool and we saw this with other tools like Tana and so on where now the new wave came of people loving to add the audio transcriptions to their note-taking apps but then we see something like Whisper Flow that makes it really independent from all the other tools and now the really the getting back to the original context here. How do you approach this? How far do you want to go with whisper flow when it comes to the feature set and being dependent focusing on text boxes or will you become a fullyfledged productivity hub or whatever? So that's really I'm interested in to learn more about and obviously the viewers too I'm guessing. >> Yeah. So there's a really simple way I look at this. So way we think about this is hey if there's 8 hours a day that you're spending on your phone and computer let's say I want as much of that to happen through whisper as possible. We start off with typing which actually the average person does five hours a day. It's a lot. And as we think about the next set of things to do when you use Whisper, it learns from you across how you're using it in every single application. And so it knows a lot more about you than a single application does. And with that, what we're able to do is to take Whisper from a tool where you speak and it writes for you to a tool where you speak and it does things for you and is finally able to help you proactively, which I think is what the best technologies are going to do cuz when some tool is able to do that, you really feel that it gets you. And so when we think about about what we prioritize there, right, I don't want to build an app which lets you book a flight because yes, it seems really cool. But people barely do that. What I would rather spend time building is, hey, what is a thing you do 20 times a day? How can I make your life better when you do that? Cuz it's likely not the best use of your time. And that is the thing that we would automate first and follow it up in that order. >> I love this approach. That's exactly what what uh I think over and over too. So or what I mentioned before, people think they may need this and then just because it's possible developers start developing it. But do I really want to have AI booking my flight? And the thing is we teach in the paperless movement in our coaching as well a lot. We get this a lot. We have a lot of business owners and CEOs and then we get these people saying I just hired a new personal assistant or I'm using now a motion for example that manages my calendar and lays out a task on the calendar and moves the due dates. And this is insane. This this makes really things worse. We see it over and over. people who are not productive in the first place become even less productive because they lose even more control where they haven't have enough control in the first place. So that's why we always compare it the digital world first to paper and to human. So if I >> cannot give a personal assistant just tell him hey book this flight and he books a flight first class you know the most expensive thing with six stops on the way there's no context that I gave to the personal assistant so how should it be able to make the best decision for me and if I define this for the personal assistant it will never work for the AI so I have to start with myself and get the workflows right and that's why using something like whisper flow it becomes really useful uh in this sense too that I can uh well it's in a personal space I I the what you just mentioned that you the the goal is not to automate your work but make it easier to work in the digital area this is really a good approach and I'm really happy to hear that but what are your thoughts about this you know human versus AI in this context >> it's a very good analogy Because that's how I think about whisper, right? And all AI tools in general, we have gotten to a point where as a person, you have the same expectations from an AI tool as you do with a person. You feel the same emotions towards an AI as you do with a person. When you give charge GPD something, it's like, hey, can you make this better? And it doesn't do a good job. You react the same way as you would with a very mediocre intern. Cuz that is the level of of quality of response that you're getting. And so what that means is what people are doing today when they're using an AI tool is they're actually hiring this AI tool as as though if they were hire a person to do a job for them. And when I think about that, that shows up in our product thinking in a couple of ways. Number one is what are the emotions that we're making the person feel and what is the mental model that we're building in this person's mind about the product. So take an example of of this thing. U say you ask an intern to draft something for you. This does a poor job but you give them feedback and the next time they get it right. We've all felt this before and then you feel so much more trust with that person even though they made a mistake. It doesn't matter. What matters is that when you coach them, they'll learn. And that is a big part that we had in flow from from day zero. When you fix a mistake, flow learns from it. And it tells you what it has learned. >> And this is actually I just have to interrupt here. This is something I noticed out of the box and I made it immediately better than alternatives in my opinion because I saw the note coming up. I updated this for the next time. I keep this in mind and this was already amazing and the next thing I was searching for is giving my own input for the words that I'm usually wrong pronouncing or anything like that and boom it was there and then I thought these guys are on the right track so yeah sorry but uh I can just >> I love to see your excitement on it because that is what we hoped we would get from users and at the end of the day you think about it's a it's a really simple notification right that is all it is but it makes the world of a difference if you start thinking about building your AI tools as you would expect a really smart intern to respond. The other big part that comes about it is about reliability. Can you fully delegate something to this person? If you can't and you have to doublech checkck their work all the time, this person's getting fired. What that looks like in the product sense is if your AI system is not able to do the thing that it does reliably, people are going to churn. people are going to stop using it or asking it to do anything ever again. Best example in case Siri promised it can do a thousand things. It can maybe do >> my theory just started when you said it. The thing is I have you know uh um dynamic dynamic lights and things like that. That's the only thing I control with Siri with very specific words. >> Yes. >> And uh this is it. everything else I rather don't ask because I just have to laugh otherwise >> because maybe Siri made a mistake once before >> and then initially you're like oh maybe I made a mistake and then it made a mistake again I was like you know what never mind this is the thing that is stupid >> I mean that's exactly it right automations are amazing as long they are working and this was already before the area era of AI that was exactly it if you have these Philips Hue lamps and all these things this is amazing But when you go into your living room and you cannot switch on the light because the Wi-Fi is down or whatever, this is the frustration that comes up now and that goes into exactly in your direction that you said with the reliability because that was the first thinking. How you know when I talk for 3 hours uh well let's three when I talk for 3 minutes into whisper how can I be sure that this is actually being recorded and that is something that's always a big worry and then I recognized oh it actually captures not only it it oh the thing is after these three minutes and you have selected the wrong box and it doesn't fill out the text box it's gone so therefore I looked into whisper and boom what is there you have a history of all the recordings that I can go through like a note takingaking app also it's not a note takingaking app for all everybody out there but I like that that is there I can reuse the things and that was amazing next checkbox so just already confirmed what you mentioned there when it comes to reliability well done >> the so the reliability is it not losing the thing but also getting the work done properly every single time when you look at a lot of the AI tools that are being built today they build the capability, hey, we can do this thing for you, but they can't do that thing really well where I can fully delegate the task over. And that I think is the biggest blocker that these tools see in adoption. And that's why when you use a new AI tool, you check out something and then you realize a month later that you never went back to it again. The biggest reason is because you didn't trust it. And so what that gets us to in in our decision and our our thinking essentially is if I ship five features in the next year, I want those to be one these five features to put should uh put a smile on people's faces. And two, they should build trust and work 100% reliable every single time. And I would rather do that than build 50 things that all seem really sexy, but work only half the time. Yeah, 100%. And I know big productivity companies, again not naming anyone, but they roll out huge AI features even for teams. And I worry a lot about any team member using the tools because it would mess up complete project management, business knowledge management, things like this. This is crazy. It's it's even dangerous because if you have planned out a lot of things and you give control without feedback loops and things like that, this is insane and as you said they over and over we see it's not reliable. It's it's we are still in the beginning and it's good that companies push so hard so we see more and more improvements in the area and the competition ensures that things eventually get right. But we always appreciate companies like here whisperflow but Hepabase is another example that really have a vision behind this and follow up exactly this the strategy behind this the framework they built and bring solutions to exact the problem that we're thinking about and not about hey here I have an API connection to open AAI tell me what I need to build right and and then you get something random this that's really a good approach there. I wonder and actually I wondered about the iOS integration of whisper flow. I don't know about Android as I'm only on iOS but this is very well executed as I also keep in mind all the obstacles you must have gone through to implement it this way. So maybe you can share a bit more with all the restrictions on Apple to make it possible that I can use whisper flow in my in my keyboard and maybe you can also share um some insights about privacy and things like that if people are worried about this. >> Of course and I can actually show a quick demo of how this works. So what we have is this keyboard on iOS where you can just press this button and you can speak and you oh tap it again and then text shows up perfectly formatted wherever you are. >> And the best thing about this is it works in every single application and it's the same keyboard. When you're also using it on the desktop version, it learns about people you care about, your writing style and so on. So that is shared on mobile as well. And the biggest thing it does is, for example, I have a 10-minute walk to the office. By the time I'm here, for the first time in my life, I'm actually sending emails on my phone. I hate writing emails on my phone, but by the time I get to the office, my inbox is clear. And it is fantastic. And there were so many people I would just procrastinate sending messages to cuz I was like, I got to like just write this whole thing down. But now with Whisper, I just speak it, it writes it in my tone, and then I can just press send. And here we have to the other thing between dictation tools and the new AI way is the corrections. So if I rumble, if I make um elms, the filler words and all this gaps, it cuts it out. And if I say if I said something wrong, it just picks the best version and things like that. So I really don't have all this editing stuff up front uh afterwards after I recorded it with whisflow. So, that's really a big advantage for sure. >> Yep. 100%. And one of my favorite features about the mobile app is actually the fact that I can whisper. And so, uh, we'll see if the Okay, I'm going to pull the mic right up close to my mouth and then we're going to do a live demo of this. >> Not even hurt anything on the >> No, but there we go. >> There you go. >> There we go. >> Perfectly put it down. >> Yeah. Perfect. And this is actually something I had on mind since the beginning. Now I'm envisioning all these people in an open office. Instead of hearing the typing sound from the keyboard, now you hear everybody whispering. So I don't know if this is really a paradigm shift here. >> Yep. No, it is it is starting to happen. Like in our office, every single person has a mic that just comes up to here and they're all just silently speaking to their computers cuz you can speak so quietly. The person beside you doesn't hear a thing. And I have to admit, it comes naturally to some people more than others. I would say 60% of the people in the office started using it day zero. I was the last person to start using it. Took me a year to build the habit of actually being comfortable speaking around people. But the first couple of times you do it now, it's just it's just there. And there are some companies where we go and do a nice white glove whisper on boarding. And for them, we actually take the mics and we just set their team up with it and we're like, just give it a shot. And just one day later, you see half the company using Whisper for everything that they're doing. And it's insane how workplaces are starting to evolve. >> Yeah, that's true. I mean in the end of the day if they talk to a coworker it is really a similar situation. It's just a different perspective that people have and well it was not usual that people type on plastic keys and that was became a common thing and as soon becomes useful it will find its way. But now this being said you say they do everything with with whisper flow. Do you really think >> that there will be an boys controlled OS at any point in time as we see now China is something launching there as well uh where they say it's possible. So what are your thoughts on this? You know, a lot of people when they when they think about a voice controlled OS, what they think about is like everything's happening with voice, right? But that is actually a really poor UX because voice is great for a number of things, but not everything. Do I want to say open iMessage every single time I go to text somebody? Like, no. Clicking is just so much faster. Imagine if I'm taking a picture and I just say photo photo every time I want to click a picture. That is also just sounds so dumb. No, you just click a button. And so what I think will happen is we are going to start seeing voice first operating systems where everything can happen with voice but there are still for some things you need just point and click cuz it's so much faster. >> And so that however will become secondary and I don't think we're too far away from it. There's parts of it that we've been prototyping in house at Whisper and actually scaling the team up significantly to build this out and it is going to be one of the most magical experiences that people will will be able to see in the next couple of years. We that is by the way how Flow came out to be. Whisper was actually a hardware company and we built Flow as the operating system that ran on that hardware. And so the voice dictation part that we have exposed out as a product right now was one of the many features that we had built into it. And so we started off building the operating system and I think if we are really on a goal to transform what the layer between people and technology and have whisper be there uh this is the end goal that we're building towards and in no way is it easy to build it but I think we have the right set of principles in place within the company and the core team that makes me confident that I think we can get there. >> That sounds ambitious and well I love their approach again and and how you frame the things. Uh I also think AR could really benefit from such an OS because in the end there we have now the issue with using a mouse and keyboard and things like that. So the better I can control AR AR devices, the better our AR glass um VR glasses and things like that. So this is really exciting to see. The thing is I agree. I mean when I when it comes to design and all these things, if I need to describe everything in detail, then it's sometimes faster to be the expert and use the tool. And getting a mix of it is certainly the right way to go for sure. Mhm. >> So you said using voice not just to write faster but to think faster. >> Do I think faster because I no longer need to write? And then obviously this only applies to people who write slower than they talk, right? >> Yes. >> So what how this how does this come up? >> So the way this comes up is is really if you think about people, right? The average person types at 40 words per minute. They speak at 250 words per minute. If they're really going at it, they can go like 350 400 and but people think at about 350 400 words per minute. So when you're typing, you actually lose so much context of what's actually going on in your head. And just giving people the ability to speak opens those floodgates. So, what we've heard from people who are more just verbal thinkers is they're able to put so much more of their thoughts and context down on paper cuz the a lot of times getting through that brain frog, getting through that writer's block, like even if you might be writing like a project report for a company, right, there's still a writer's block associated there cuz you have so much context in your head and you're just worrying about, hey, how do I structure it? One of the ways I found Whisper really help people and how they describe it is Whisper takes care of just the first draft of structuring it. So you only need to focus on the ideas. And if you're not spending time thinking about where every comma and full stop comes and how different words are spelled if you're not a native English speaker, just imagine the amount of just cognitive load that it takes off of your shoulders and just puts it down back into that creative part of your mind. And that is I think what the biggest impact is. A lot of people say how it saves time. Some person compared it that it makes responding to emails 60% faster. He actually timed himself like responding to 50 emails like like side by side. And the biggest impact though that I feel is just this cognitive load that gets lifted off because it makes all of this work effortless. The work that people just don't look forward to doing at all. that in some ways is the the biggest impact that people feel and that's the one that gives them joy because it's just this constant feeling of dopamine hits every time you're you're uh saving this effort. subtitles.srt: Ever wish you could ditch typing and just talk your way through emails, notes, or even code? Today, we're comparing two heavy hitters in voice dictation: Whisper Flow and Super Whisper. By the end of this, you'll know which one's worth your time and your voice. First up, Whisper Flow. This is for anyone who wants seamless AI powered dictation across every app. Whether you're drafting emails in Gmail, coding in VS Code, or slacking off on Slack, it's crazy fast, claiming to be four times quicker than typing, and it's packed with smart features like autoedits, tone matching, and support for 100 plus languages. Needed to learn your quirky vocab. It's got a personal dictionary for that. Pricing starts free with a 2,000word weekly limit, or go pro for $15 a month for unlimited words and advanced editing commands. The trade-off, some users report occasional hiccups with system integration, and the free tier might feel tight for power users. Now, Super Whisper. This one's a beast for privacy conscious folks. It works offline, keeps everything on your device, and still nails transcription with perfect punctuation. Perfect for walks, noisy cafes, or just avoiding the cloud. It's also versatile, letting you whisper notes and then spit them out as polished emails or docs. The free version covers basics, but the pro plan unlocks cloud models and translation for $8.49 per month. Downsides, the mobile app isn't as slick as Whispers yet, and longer dictations might need a pause button. So, who wins? If you need deep app integration, AI smarts, and team features, Whisper Flows your pick. But if offline privacy and simplicity matter more, Super Whisper's the move. Either way, your keyboard's about to get a very long

title: Voice + AI: My Complete Productivity System using Raycast, Wispr Flow,  Asana MCP
text:
I didn't realize my daily AI workflow was unusual until everyone kept asking for details, so I finally made this video showing how I combine voice commands and AI to manage my daily tasks.

Raycast: https://www.raycast.com/hey/375621af

Asana: https://asana.com/

ü§ì If you're already familiar with Raycast and Wispr Flow, you might want to jump to 8:30 where I focus on the Raycast MCP Client and an integration with Asana.

Video Overview:
‚è±Ô∏è 00:00 - Introduction
‚è±Ô∏è 00:30 - Raycast overview and benefits
‚è±Ô∏è 01:20 - Wispr Flow for voice dictation
‚è±Ô∏è 02:15 - Clipboard history in Raycast

I'm Dave, the co-founder of Reflection, an AI-powered journaling app.

If you're interested in mental health and personal growth enhanced by AI, check it out: https://www.reflection.app

subtitles.srt: Ever feel like your thoughts flow faster than your fingers can type? Yeah, that's because they actually do. We speak almost three times faster than we type. Which means every time you're stuck hammering on a keyboard, your ideas are already miles ahead. So, what do you do? You go to voice to text tools like Whisper Flow. They let you speak naturally and turn your words into text instantly. While whisper flow makes the process beautifully simple, it does have a lot of hiccups with background noise, editing control, and device compatibility. So, if you love Whisper Flow but wish it did just a little more, here are five powerful alternatives that take voice to text to the next level. [Music] So, let's start with the first one, ClickUp. ClickUp is the world's first converged AI workspace built to end work in AI sprawl. With its talkto text feature, you can capture ideas up to four times faster than typing in over 40 languages. And because it's powered by contextaware AI, it recognizes your teammates names, your projects, and even document titles as you speak. Then there's Brainax, your desktop AI super app that keeps your entire workspace connected. It can search through every note, doc, or task within your ClickUp workspace and connected apps to pull answers to get work done in seconds. ClickUp makes sure you never lose your best ideas to context switching and tab hopping. It's the one intelligent workspace that brings everything together. Moving on to our next tool, Otter AI. Otter listens to your conversations in real time and types them out verbatim for you. No matter what meeting you're taking or when you need the summary, Otter can figure things out for you. But remember, Otter sometimes needs a tuneup. If there's a lot of background noise or people talking over each other, you may not get the best results. Still, for fast and easy note-taking, Otter is a real lifesaver. Now, if Otter is your meeting sidekick, then Sony's AI is the language wizard, just one that lives in your pocket. Sonox is great if you've got teammates from different countries or you need your notes in more than one language. You just drop in your audio or video, and Sonics turns it to text in over 40 languages with no problem. You can polish your transcript, highlight the important stuff, and share it with others. But here's the catch. If you're using it a lot, you'll probably need to pay for extra transcriptions once the free trial runs out. The fourth tool on our list is Mac Whisper. This one is just for Mac users. What's cool about Mac Whisper is that it works even if you don't have internet access. Since everything is stored locally on your computer, your notes are also private and safe. Just record your voice and Mac Whisper turns it into text. No cloud dependency. No worries. The only thing is if you're not a Mac user, you're out of luck. Mac Whisper doesn't work on Windows or mobile devices. Last but not least, we have dictote. Dictote is kind of like talking to yourself. You can speak freely and it writes down what you say. You can even use voice in it. It's speechto text extension on the Chrome web store. This reduces the need for fast internet and helps keep your voice data more private. Dictote works best on Google Chrome. So, if you're using a different browser or want to use it on your phone, it might not be the perfect fit for you. And that wraps up our list. Five awesome alternatives to Whisper. title: Wispr Flow vs Superwhisper vs Otter.ai: AI Voice Dictation Comparison 2025
text:
In this video, we dive deep into the ultimate comparison of AI voice dictation tools: Wispr Flow, Superwhisper, and Otter.ai. Discover which tool stands out in 2025 for accuracy, ease of use, and unique features. Whether you're a student, professional, or content creator, finding the right voice dictation software can enhance your productivity and streamline your workflow.

We analyze key aspects such as transcription speed, voice recognition capabilities, and integration with other applications. Learn about the pros and cons of each tool, and see real-time demonstrations to help you make an informed decision. 

Join us as we explore user experiences, pricing options, and the latest updates for each platform. Don't miss out on this comprehensive guide to choosing the best AI voice dictation tool for your needs in 2025!

If you find this video helpful, please like, share, and subscribe for more content on AI tools and technology comparisons. 

#WisprFlow #Superwhisper #OtterAI #VoiceDictation #AIComparison #ProductivityTools #TechReview #appreview

subtitles.srt: Welcome to the deep dive. Today we're jumping into AI audio transcription tools. It's uh it's more than just speed now, isn't it? >> Oh, absolutely. Speed's almost a given. We're talking accuracy. Often hitting over 95% super fast processing. AI is definitely replacing manual work fast, >> right? So, what we want to do today is compare these tools, but maybe look past just the speed things like, you know, data privacy, how well they handle different languages, and what they're actually best for. >> Exactly. Is it for dictation or maybe transcribing big meetings? Because that choice you make, it could be about convenience. Sure. But it might also impact your data security without you realizing it. >> Okay, let's start there then. The security part that seems critical, especially if you're handling sensitive stuff, medical files maybe, or confidential research interviews. >> That's the highest priority for many users. And it comes down to this core divide, how the tool is built. Is it local or cloud? >> Local versus cloud. Explain that difference. >> Sure. So local or ondevice tools, think of things like the open- source model whisper or uh Super Whisper, which is Mac only. They do all the processing right there on your machine, >> meaning the audio file itself never goes anywhere. >> Precisely. It never leaves your device. So for confidentiality, that's inherently the safer path. No third party servers involved. >> But I guess the immediate question is, do you lose something by keeping it local? maybe fewer features or is it slower than the big cloud platforms? >> That can be the perception. Yeah, sometimes there's a tradeoff. But if security is paramount, it might be a trade-off you have to make. >> Okay. So, what about the other side, the cloud tools, >> right? So, platforms like Otter.ai or TR, maybe Rev, they work differently. Your audio gets uploaded and processed on their remote servers. Often that's Amazon Web Services, AWS, or maybe Microsoft Azure. And that immediately rings alarm bells for things like GDPR or hypo compliance. >> It definitely can. You're introducing another party that handles your data. And there's sort of a hidden aspect, too. >> What's that? >> Well, many of these cloud services, um, Otter.AI and Rev included, their default setting is often to use your d your audio, your transcripts to actually train their own AI models. >> Wow. So, your confidential conversations could be feeding their algorithm >> potentially. Yes. Now sometimes you can opt out but you need to actively look for that setting for journalists, lawyers, anyone dealing with sensitive sources. That's a huge consideration. >> Okay, so architecture clearly defines the security level. Let's pivot to workflow. How you actually use these tools day-to-day, >> right? Because a tool might be secure but completely wrong for your needs. >> Makes sense. >> Let's talk about meetings first. Otter.ai seems to own that space, doesn't it? >> It really does. It's built for collaboration. integrates slickly with Zoom, with Teams. It can even, you know, track who attended automatically. Really shines in that group setting. >> Yeah, there must be downsides. >> Yeah, the main ones are needing constant internet access. It is cloud-based after all. And the free version is well, pretty tight. You only get 30 minutes per recording and just 300 minutes total per month. >> Okay. So, what's the alternative? If you're not primarily recording meetings, maybe just dictating notes or emails, >> then you look at tools more focused on personal productivity, uh things like Super Whisper again or maybe Willow Voice. They're designed for quick voice to text across lots of different apps on your computer, >> like the Old Dragon Naturally Speaking software, but uh hopefully better. >> Well, yes and no. They're generally much faster and more accurate for straight transcription. But here's a common frustration people have actually coming from that Dragon legacy. >> What's that? >> Those older tools were really good at voice commands. You could say new paragraph or open parenthesis and it would do it. These newer AI tools, they often just transcribe those words literally. >> Ah, so they hear new paragraph and just type out new paragraph. >> Exactly. It can be quite frustrating if you're used to dictating formatting and structure that way. They're more about pure transcription speed. >> Interesting distinction. Okay, let's talk raw performance and accuracy. There's been research on this, right? >> Yes, quite a bit. A recent study, I think it was out of Germany's Institute of Media Research did a head-to-head. They found Whisper, the underlying model for many tools, performed quote, best overall. >> Best overall based on what? >> Across several criteria. For instance, in German language interviews, it hit a word accuracy measure above 70%. Which is pretty solid for complex multi-speaker audio. And who was at the other end of the scale in that study? >> That was actually Dragon. The study found it was the least reliable for transcribing those kinds of multis-speaker interviews. Its accuracy in the German test, it dropped below 5%. >> Wow. Below 5% that's a basically unusable for interview. >> It really underlines that Dragon was built for a single trained voice giving commands, not for separating different speakers in a messy realworld conversation. >> But even the best tools aren't perfect. Yeah. >> You mentioned Whisper being top overall, but there's this risk of what what did you call it? Hallucination. >> Exactly. Hallucination. It's a known issue with large language models which power these tools. Even Whisper, despite its high accuracy, isn't immune. >> What does that mean in practice? >> Well, in high stakes areas like healthcare documentation, studies have shown Whisper can sometimes just invent things, non-existent facts, maybe treatments that weren't discussed, even policies that don't exist. >> How often does that happen? One study found it occurred in about 1.4% of medical transcriptions using whisper. Now 1.4% sounds small, but in a medical or legal context, inventing information like that carries massive risks, huge liability. >> Okay, so pulling this all together, the main message seems to be there's no single best app. It's about matching your specific need, privacy, speed, collaboration to the tools fundamental design, its architecture. >> Precisely. And if confidentiality is your absolute top priority, especially dealing with sensitive research or personal data, then local ondevice processing is technically always going to be the safest bet, even if it means sacrificing a few bells and whistles. >> So, we know now really that every automated transcript needs a human review. A human in the loop is essential. >> Absolutely critical. >> But thinking about that 1.4% hallucination rate in medicine, it makes you wonder, doesn't it? Knowing these powerful AI tools can actively invent information, how many less obvious errors, maybe non-existent facts or subtly wrong details, might be hiding in the transcripts you rely on right

subtitles.srt: Hey guys, my name is Robert. Recently I have noticed that dictation tools are becoming more and more popular with the rise of AI applications. It's a big topic, but here I will just give you an overview of some applications that I have tried, their pros and cons, and I also want to show you how to do this for free, locally, and without the internet. While Whisper and similar models are not perfect, when combined with LLMs, the time-saving potential and everything that you can do is kind of mind-blowing. Let me break this down in a more simple way. There are two main parts to this new AI dictation that we're starting to see around. First, there's transcription. That's where the speech-to-text AI model turns your voice into text. The second part involves running that text through a large language model, or LLM for short. This is where a lot of the cool stuff happens. LLMs, like Chagipity, can improve grammar, format text, translate, summarize, restructure. It can answer questions, help with coding, explain complex topics, and so much more. It really is like having a super smart assistant with you. By combining highly accurate transcription with these powerful language models, we are opening up a whole new world of possibilities. It's an impressive integration of voice and text technologies. I'll cover some popular apps that use dictation that can be run through language models. For this example, I will just be using OpenAI Cloud. and it's really cool that they also allow you to use this. Let me go inside the dictation area. Here you can set, well, on the top we have a video showing you a little bit how this works. Then we can set up our own custom keyboard shortcut to start dictating. And here we have an area where you can select a prompt. I will start with nothing, but the AI service that I will choose will be GPT-40 mini. This one is not the smartest model, but it's pretty fast. You can choose between many different services here. You can choose even local models, and that's a very nice recent addition. Let me go back in dictation. And down here, you can make your own different prompts if you want the transcription to be processed like I was explaining to you a moment ago. I will start with nothing. And here, for example, cleanup. This one will just have fixed grammar mistakes, spelling, stuff like that. This one will translate. And this one is just AI assistant. I will show you how that works in one moment. This one only says this. Now let me just start dictating so you can see how it looks in action. And I am dictating. I'm speaking to my microphone and this should be transcribed. And I press the shortcut again. And there it is. And actually, even though I didn't run my text through any AI prompt, it still looks okay. The point with running our transcribed text through an AI prompt is that many times, and this applies to all of the applications that use Whisper, by the way, I mean, there's some limitations on regards to how the model works. It will not insert line breaks between paragraphs, for example. Sometimes it will make mistakes with punctuation marks. So even if it's simple stuff, you can ask it, you know what, can you clean up my text? Can you just make sure that all the punctuation is correct? And of course, you can start to do more things. Here in Mac Whisper, here is where the things start to get a little bit frustrating for me. Let me start dictating and I will change to an AI prompt. So here I am. I think this can be fixed. Also, the way that the text is inserted is character by character, which I think also is not ideal because if you dictate a lot, it will go like typing text by text. The development team seems to keep all of this information secret, which, to be honest, is kind of worrying. It was able to understand my selected text and expand on it. Not only that, I can also go a little bit below and again, ask. Super Whisper has something called modes. Let me show you.
