You know, all of that because of the control that the user has and because of the power that the developer has allowed the user to have access to with all of these settings, with all of this configuration. My favorite apps are those that allow you to expand your interaction with them, with your own needs, ideas, and customization. And because of that, I love this. There's so much to say about Super Whisper. It really is one of my most used and favorite apps right now. So, as positives, Super Whisper, in my opinion, has the perfect amount of features to be used either for dictation or as an AI assistant. Like I said, you have total control over customizing different modes. I use it for writing ideas, structuring outlines, summarizing, coding, dictating and helping with grammar, or structuring video scripts like the one that you're watching right now. Super Whisper also has similar context awareness features as Whisper Flow. This feature is optional and you can set it up per mode, but it's amazing for interacting with both typed text and voice. As I was telling you, with Super Whisper, not only you have the option of pasting the result directly on your front window, like the previous two applications do, but you also have the option of having that separate recording window that we saw in the settings. and I actually use that a lot more because I can go to any application or I can be on any website and I can select some text and I can say, please simplify this for me because it's too complicated for me to understand. And in this kind of situation, of course, I don't need the text pasted to my front window. and in case I do need that I can just go to a note and I can just paste because I know that I have that on my clipboard. Super Whisperer offers a subscription but aside from that there's also a lifetime payment option currently priced at $250. It took me like five minutes of testing the app to decide to buy it not only because of all the features but also I don't know where else I'll find unlimited access to models like Sonnet 3.5 or GPT-40 at this kind of price. I know that new models are coming out every other day, but what is included here is really, really good and the developer keeps the app up to date. The negatives? Well, the lifetime option isn't exactly cheap. I think it's absolutely worth it, but it's a bit of an investment off front. You can also go with a subscription if you prefer. If you are not into tinkering with settings, you might also find it a little bit overwhelming at first. There's definitely a learning curve for the more advanced stuff. While one of Super Whisperer's biggest strengths is all of the settings and control that the user can have, this can also lead to confusion and misunderstandings about how the app works. My biggest concern with Super Whisperer is that currently it seems that it's only one developer handling coding, marketing, business, and customer service. While most effort goes into app development and fixing serious bugs, I just don't know how much bandwidth there is for growth. So far, I can see that important bugs and issues from users do get attention. It just worries me a bit because I've seen app developers become totally unreachable after getting more popular, and I think that this app has the potential to become pretty big. So, unless there's a few more team members, I don't know about this in the future. It's still impressive that the developer has done everything by himself, and I'm grateful to have this app. So I'm very, very happy to recommend it. And iCo also uses Whisper for transcription, and actually this application is not originally made for dictation, but the really, really cool thing about this app, Well, number one, it's free. Number two, it uses Whisper models, which are very accurate, like I was showing you and telling you before. But this one has integration with shortcuts. So I created a small shortcut that I will be sharing with you. Basically, with iCode, and let me go to the Shortcuts app. Let me open the shortcut that I made. I have another application, which is called LM Studio. And with LM Studio, you can download open source AI models. And there's, for example, Lama 3.2, which is pretty good. And you can set up like a local server. And this works totally offline. I will start it here. Start. And here with a shortcut, you do not even have to change anything. And this shortcut will work offline. using ICO and LM Studio. If you have something like Olama, you probably have to go down here and change the URL for that, but it also works with cloud models if you want. So if you enter cloud here and if you enter your token here in this space, then it will use OpenAI Whisper and it will use the model that you set here. So this shortcut can work both for local or for online. And again, like we saw before, everything will depend on the system prompt. So here we have this field where you can say you are a translator. Hello, I am just testing this and I'm making sure that it works properly. And again, the Ico takes that sends it to LM Studio and I get the result and I set it like this as a pop-up because I feel like this shortcut is so basic and it's a great opportunity for you to also understand how this works if you want a behavior like the one that we were getting in the other apps you can actually just put some script there Apple script so that it can press command v one thing I have to mention is that the shortcuts app has this time limitation when making online requests. If it takes too long, the app will quit. This is a problem because if your dictation is too long and LM Studio takes a while, or if OpenAI Server is slow to transcribe everything, then it will time out and you will end up with nothing. But don't worry, if that happens, know that the latest transcription file, the audio file, is always in your shortcuts folder. That's a good backup, and you can just go there, select the right click and share it to the shortcut to try transcribing again. That's there as a safety net so you don't lose your last dictation. If you plan to use this for longer recordings, for that case I actually created a copy of the shortcut and I connected it to Keyboard Maestro as a macro. and I will be giving you also that one in the description of the video, in that link. And with that one, you don't have to worry about the limitation of the Shortcuts app because the actual processing with the local model will be done by Keyboard Maestro, and that's much more flexible. Again, that one will also appear as a pop-up, and you can just decide to paste it or do something else with it. For even longer files, you probably have to do some tests, and you probably will want to do everything with Keyboard Maestro and skip the shortcuts app totally. But that's beyond the simple alternative that I wanted to share here. As I'm wrapping up this video, I just want to tell you, if you want the absolutely best that I have tried so far, there's Super Whisperer. Also, a few months ago, I made an Alfred workflow called Kiki, and the reason that I'm so familiar with this topic is because Kiki incorporates a similar functionality to Super Whisperer. You can do a lot of the same things. The problem is, well, it's not super easy to set up. There's a long documentation, and maybe in the future I will make some more tutorials for it. But unless you know how to deal with AppleScript and trigger Alfred workflows externally with arguments and all that, you probably don't want to mess with it. It's also super powerful, and you use it with your own API tokens. But I just found this new app, and well, Super Whisper gives me very good models for a one-time payment. so I am mostly using this for now. If you don't want advanced features, there's Mac Whisper, which is a bit rough on the edges when it comes to dictation, but still very good for its price, especially if you also need file transcriptions and subtitle creation. As I said, I can only expect this app to get better with time. But if you need dictation alone, maybe you'll be totally okay with something like the shortcut that I shared with you. title: Wispr Flow: Speech to Text Like Never Before
text:
In this episode Tanika Mehra interviews Tanay Kothari, Co-founder & CEO of Wispr Flow, an AI-powered voice-first productivity tool designed to help professionals communicate faster and more naturally. 


Wispr Flow is pioneering a screen-free, voice-first future where professionals can dictate messages, edit text with natural voice commands, and boost productivity 3x faster than typing. Backed by NEA, 8VC, and top AI leaders, Wispr Flow has raised $26M to redefine the way we interact with technology.

subtitles.srt: [Music] Hello everyone, welcome to Wharton Tech Talks. I'm your host Taneka and today we have Tanekari. He is the co-founder and CEO of Whistler Flow, an AI powered voice first productivity tool designed to help professionals communicate faster and more naturally. Tani has been obsessed with building technology since his teenage years, launching over 50 apps and he has represented India at an international computing and linguistic competition. Before Whisper, he worked on AI and product teams at leading startups to gain hands-on experience building scalable AIdriven platforms. Whisper Flow is a pioneering screen first, voice first future, where professionals can dictate messages, edit with natural language, voice commands, and boost productivity, which is over three times faster than typing. Backed by NEA, 8VC and other top AI leaders, Whisper Flow has raised 26 million to redefine the way we interact with technology. Welcome, Tan. >> Hey, Taneka, thanks for having me here. >> Awesome. So could you share a little bit more about your background and the inception of Whisper? >> Yeah, of course. We started the company some time back, but it's been an idea that I've been working on for pretty much the last 16 years, which is what should the next generation of computing really feel like. Back in 2008 when the first Iron Man movie came out, I wanted to build Jarvis. So me and a friend of mine built what was then one of the world's first voice assistants. And to people, it just felt like magic. It grew to about 2 and a half million users. Google shut us down with a cease and desist. My dad was mad at me. It was a whole series of things that happened. But to me, this idea was just very top of mind for the next decade pretty much, which was really like tapping on icons on a screen and clicking keys on a keyboard as the best way to communicate just feels like a ridiculous idea to me. So when I think about technology, what it should really feel like, I want it to be something that understands me, maybe even better than I understand myself. I want it to be something where interacting with it feels just as natural as interacting with other people. And if you're building a system like this, then it eventually becomes something that becomes a part of people's identity. And everything that we're building at Whisper now is all in those lines of where we want technology to go towards. >> That's incredible. And that's a funny story about you watching Iron Man and then just wanting to build this product out of that. But with so much of our work today happening on screens, what do you see as the biggest challenge in people transitioning to just a voice first future? I think a lot of what we do on our computers today, you can divide it into categories. For some things, you do need a screen. If you're consuming content, you need a screen. If you're reading large swats of text, you need a screen. If you're in discovery mode, you're looking at a bunch of options, maybe you're shopping for a new dress, all of that, you need a screen. But for a lot of small things, you don't. You don't need a screen to quickly reply to a text message. You don't need a screen to send a new calendar invite. And there's a whole list of things there. The thing that I'm really going after is for a lot that you do today on your phones and your laptops. What parts of it are just way better to have as a voice first interface and let's build that so you aren't building towards a world where people are stuck on their screens always. They can do a lot which is something that exists in the background and them as people can be a lot more present with their heads up looking out into the world. >> Yeah, that's very fair. So what do you think was like one of the first few use cases that at Whisper you guys have been focusing on kind of guiding people to use voice versus their keyboards and looking at screens. >> The biggest thing that we started off with so actually whisper flow was the eighth product that we built internally. The first seven were what you would expect if you hear voice interfaces. It would do actions for you. I could say things like, "Hey, I want to meet Taneka for dinner. Can you make a reservation at a restaurant nearby?" Send her a message and make a calendar invite. And it did all of that. It was beautiful. And this I'm talking about 2021. So this is pre when AI agents were a real thing. But the thing was nobody in our company used it. I used it maybe once and then I forgot it existed. Because what we realized is when you're building any consumer tool, what you need is to really have people build a habit. And you can't build a habit with very infrequent use cases. So then what we built towards was voice dictation. Super simple. You speak naturally and it writes perfectly formatted in your style across all your applications. It went from something that I maybe used once a day to a tool that I now use hundreds of times a day. And some people use actually this a lot more than even I do. And that has really strong habit building potential. >> So that's really how I think about scaling back product development is building the one thing people do 100 times a day. Then the 10 things that people do 10 times a day and then we go and build a 100 things that people would do one time a day because at that point they're already bought in. They're already using it and now we're just adding a lot more value. >> That makes sense. I'm a huge fan of the product. I use it a lot. myself, but for our audience who might not be familiar, could you tell us how is it different from something like a auto AI or something like voice to text that you use on your iPhone? >> If you have ever used voice to text to send a message to anybody, you know that you are terrified at what it's going to produce and if you're going to have to go back and fix the mistakes that it makes. Flow doesn't make mistakes. It's primarily because we've optimized it to get you outputs that don't need editing. It's very specifically what we built the platform for. And it came from an insight that we had which was people speak very differently than they write. You stammer, you stutter, you change your mind halfway while speaking. You speak in long rambles and sentences that are 100 words long. But when you're writing that is not what you want to write at all. So flow does small things like if I say hey let's meet at 5:00 actually you know what let's do 6 p.m. Flo writes hey let's meet at 6 p.m. cuz that is literally what I would have written if I give it a long set of things like hey I have three thoughts here like firsta d and all of that flow would format my message when I'm dropping it in slack as bullet points so my team doesn't bang their head against the wall and try to read like a whole thing that I send them but it's instead a very structured message. These are few things that we do that just make people use flow for everything and make it to a point where people don't really have to edit that much. >> That's fair. And would you say when people see the quality and caliber of what flow can do in terms of reducing editing that feeds into your thesis that it'll become more of a habit that people use every day? >> It does. And initially it was a hypothesis. Six months ago when we launched the product, we had no idea how people were actually going to use it. All we knew was for the six people on the team how we like to use it. But people keep surprising us day in day out. For people who've used Flow for a month, did you know that they use Flow more than their keyboard on their computers? Measurably. And this is the first time any software on the planet has replaced people's keyboards. This has never happened before in the history of computing. Keyboards have just been as much of a staple as you can imagine. Right. >> Definitely. I mean, spending less time typing and more time speaking would definitely make communication more personal as well, which is something that I'm excited to see. Could you tell us about like a pivotal moment that you faced early on that kind of set in stone that what you're doing is the right thing for you. Yeah, I think it was the example that I'd given earlier about going from building a tool that does actions for you to voice dictation. And for a lot of people who look to start companies, right? If somebody was like came to me like T, let's start a voice dictation company. I'd be like, that doesn't really sound sexy. This exists in so many places. Like I don't know about this. Somebody's like, oh, let's build this thing that can control your computer and do all these cool actions. Like that sounds a lot sexier. But when you actually get down to it, it doesn't really matter what it sounds like. What matters is do people use it? Does it build habit? Do people pay for it? Is this on a path to a much larger vision that you have? And on that note, like a big realization I had is there's no feature or product that's big or small. It doesn't matter how cool something sounds. All that matters at the end of the day is what your users tell you. >> That makes sense. Can you tell us about your journey like how you took from scaling your idea of whisper to a fully operational business today? >> Yeah, the first versions of Whisper we had internally. We gave it to a few users and the base slowly grew on from there. And for a long time we decided actively not to charge people for it. We wanted to see okay if you just have this product does this build have it? And we didn't want to put any blockers in front of people for that. So we got that got it to a point and it was really funny because we had the other problem where people were skeptical. Why is this product for free? This product is so good. Are they selling my data? How is this company not charging for it? And in October of last year, we decided to launch the paid plans. And to our surprise, a lot of people started paying for it. So usually I was expecting 5% of users to pay for the product which is what you see as usual for any company. You compare the Dropboxes, notions and all in the world and our numbers were more than twice that of the percent of people that were switching over to being paid users. That to us was a big sign like okay this is adding a lot of value to people's lives and for some reason they really want to pay for it. And then was the second phase of it of let's really start to understand what the user journey looks like. Spending time with people and like what made you download this application? How did you hear about it? What made you want to start using it more? What was your first aha moment? Why did you pay for this thing? Why did you not pay for this thing? and really getting answers to all the questions was really helpful to revamp the whole user journey and flow that we have restructure the company to start to put itself in a lot more product first mature way starting to onboard larger enterprises teams and so on and it's just going from there but I think a big part of it was just leading with curiosity and all of those questions at every step of the way helped drive the transitions that we needed to make pretty much at this point every two months. >> That's great. And I'm glad to hear you got such good feedback from your customers and you're seeing it in growth in paid users. But could you tell us a little bit about what strategies you're using to grow your user base and expand your market presence? I've seen that really funny video that you have of taking the axe to the keyboard or this bus or whatever. But apart from that, are there any other marketing strategies that you've used? >> Yeah. Yeah, a bunch of them. So one thing that makes marketing our product very unique is people by default hate voice dictation. Like if you say Siri, you just see the disgust on people's faces, right? That's the best experience they've had. >> So we can't go out there ourselves and be like we have really good voice dictation for you. Cuz people are like, "Yeah, Siri's been saying that for the last 10 years and I know what they give me." And for a lot of products that can just do that, that leads to very different marketing channels. Ours had to be a lot more social proof driven. So instead of that, the things that we had is how do we empower our users to post more about it to share it in different places so that they users are not just seeing like hey this is a tool. This is just people saying this is what Apple should have built and people are like huh that is right. city does suck, but is there something better? And it grabs their attention. And I would say 95% of our growth has just been organic through word of mouth referrals, through users posting it on Slack channels, users like you putting me on podcasts. So we can dive a bit more into flow and I can share more of the stories behind it. >> Yeah, this is a shout out to all the listeners. Please try it out. I think it's fantastic and it'll save you a lot of time. and then tell you about one of my favorite features which is the auto editing tool. Could you tell the audience about how the system works? How does it understand context to make real-time corrections when people are speaking? That way it's different from the other dictation tools as you mentioned where you have to pause and it calibrates what you said. Here it actually listens, understands and then edits. >> Yeah, that's a huge part. You know, when I think about flow, I I think about less as voice dictation like a tool like Otter and more so as if there was a person sitting on your computer and you are telling them some email to send whatever. What would they do? Well, if you like this person, then they're most likely competent. They're very good at writing. They have a good understanding of you. So, if you're a professional, you write professional emails, they're not going to drop in emojis in there. And third is they are reliable. So they reliably work every single time and you can trust them. That is really important. Those were the characteristics that we wanted to build into the product. For example, Tanek, if I'm sending a message to you, it's never going to get your name wrong. It's like right there on the screen. It's crazy to me that other things get your name wrong and other things don't use this context that is very readily available. The other things that we do is instead of writing everything you say word for word we have built our own models that understand you what you're saying what the context is and based on that what really should be written and there's one thing that we're going to be be building out soon is for it to sometimes give you suggestions as well based on how you usually write on what you could do better ways in which you could improve right there and then less so on grammar grammar and such, but more so just the content of your ideas cuz it starts to have context of what you're saying across different applications. If you wrote something in notion, then you're writing an email somewhere else. It starts to build a better mental model of you. >> That's fair. And so it kind of learns and understands what the user likes and what the user talks about and what apps the user uses becomes more intelligent. the more you use it, the better it understands you and the more effectively you can use the tools. That's great. >> And you've mentioned that you're trying to build a world where people aren't glued to their screens all day. What would you imagine a voice first world to look 10 years from now? >> I walk down the street looking around. People are not stuck on their phones texting away. They are just looking up. you as just people can just enjoy a lot more of what the world looks like, what people around you and interact more with them. Things like screen time and such feel like outdated concepts. I feel like tracking screen time and trying to reduce screen time is a band-aid solution to the problem we have, which is literally everything you do, you need to stare at a screen to do it. And then we're like, "Oh, we're going to reduce screen time and we're going to download like five apps that block other apps and do this other thing." And it's like, yes, sure, but that is not the way to really do it. What you really need to do is kind of rethink the problem from the ground up, which is humans weren't meant to stare at screens all the time. We're meant to communicate. We're meant to be understood. We're meant to share some context, see things happen. I recently tried out this tool, Sesame AI, where it's like a voice assistant speaking back to you. Are you familiar with the tool? Have you thought about whether you want Whisper to eventually speak back to the user using the tool or what would you say is the next step? You mentioned also uh replacing the 100 habits that a single user does versus just changing one habit. Could you just talk about which of the two would you think would be a natural transition from your existing product? >> Having the computer speak back to you is useful in some situations. I don't think it's a catch all for everything. >> Primarily cuz sometimes if you're consuming content or like if I'm learning something more about a topic, your eyes read information so much faster than your ears can even try to process. Mhm. >> If I was trying to listen to something that I'm learning about, my impatience would get the better of me and I'll probably close the thing. I think audio output is good for certain situations and we're definitely going to build that in. The way I think about it is like, okay, let's take a workflow. What is the best experience for this workflow? Does it need to have voice output? If so, we'll add that. Does it even need to have voice input? Cuz in some situations, maybe your voice is not the best way to interact with it. you need something different and we'll build the thing that we need to just for writing voice is the best that you have. So we decided to build it that way and instead of hearing back what you said like Siri repeats back to you it's just way better to quickly glance at it on the screen. Even better if you start trusting the system and you never have to read the outputs again which is what I do. I just genuinely speak the thing and I press send. I don't even read what flow writes anymore. I know it's probably going to write the right thing. That's great that you have such implicit trust and hopefully your users feel the same way and they continue. >> We do track that across users on how long they spend when the text space on the screen >> and the time before they press enter within 2 weeks. 90% of the time it's under half a second. >> Most people for most things don't wait and read what flow writes. If at any point that drops that is a big flag to us that we need to go change it. >> Sure. Yeah. Fair enough. That's a cool metric to track. Are there any other interesting metrics that you've noticed through your user adoption? Maybe number of words spoken before they become like a lifetime user or something of that sort. >> There are some metrics like that. A couple that I find really interesting is the number of applications that they use flow in. So when I think about the user journey a person has with the product, >> they have the first aha moment during onboarding when they do their first dictation >> cuz it is insanely accurate, insanely fast and that's the first time they have experienced anything like that. They're like, "Oh, holy This is awesome. I was not expecting this at all." The second aha moment comes when they find their first use case. It could be somebody responding to all their emails, all their Slacks, using it in cursor or wind surf. They could be using it to talk to other AI systems. >> Mhm. >> Pick one. They love using that and they're like, "Okay, whenever I do this thing, I'm just going to use flow." That's the first habit that they build. And a couple of weeks from then is when they get to a point where they're typing on the keyboard somewhere and they're like, "This is so painful. Why am I doing this?" And that's when you see an explosion happen. For people who've used the product for a bit, on average, they are using Flow in across 90 different apps and websites. >> Wow, that's incredible. >> I know. I was shocked when I saw that number and I had to double check like a few times. I was like, is this real? Did I do something wrong? I was like, no, it's genuinely it's literally everything that they use. >> I think I need to think of creative ways to expand my usage horizon across more apps. Then I'll take this up as a challenge. >> Yeah. Shifting gears a little. So you guys have raised a significant amount of money. Could you talk to us about when you decided to raise? What was the process speaking to investors? How did you choose the investors to raise form and any advice that you have for aspiring entrepreneurs seeking for investments for their startups? >> Yep, happy to share some highle notes that really help me along my way. And then of course people's situations are different. So there's very unique advice I would have if I'm talking to somebody. Number one for flow made sense for us to raise from day one because we knew we needed good amount of capital to get this thing off the ground. We did that. In general with fundraisers, what you want to do as a founder is you want to have it happen in a very compressed time frame. We started the fund raise on a Monday and we told everybody we are going to close this and finalize allocations by Friday of the next week. Essentially 12-day time period. And a couple of weeks before that was when we had planned all the meetings for those two weeks. So you want to make sure everything is running at the same time. Everybody that you're talking to is running on the same schedule >> cuz the last thing you want is you receive a term sheet from somebody and you are in first stage first calls with other people. Same as applying to jobs, right? You don't have negotiating power, which is not good. So the goal is to get as much negotiating power as you possibly can, which is what happens. Then other things that were really helpful for us is for all the WC's we try to get warm intros and get the people introing us to hype us up. The conversation is already starting on a good note and we don't have to spend the first 10 minutes trying to build credibility. It's already there and so we can build on top of that and get to dream together. Note I'd make about pitch decks. There's a lot of questions that come around there. Do I need a pitch deck? Shall I just wing it and have a conversation? Shall I make a memo? I generally think use a pitch deck as essentially a presentation guide. I keep my pitch decks really short about seven, eight slides, tops five words a slide and they're just supposed to ground what I am talking about. And in terms of the conversation, I can do that in my sleep once I start fundraising cuz everything is pre-planned. There is a script for the intros for the exact presentation. Me and my co-founder went through 150 possible questions we could get asked and we had concise and very clear answers written for every single one of them that we nailed down. And when you go into any conversation with that level of preparedness, it feels to the other person like a deep sense of confidence. You're not stammering. You are not having to think twice or ponder about questions that are coming. every single number and answer you need is at your fingertips. And that is really what investors want to see cuz it was like, okay, if you come into this conversation like this, just imagine how you're going to be running the company. And that got us to have a really successful fund raise. And honestly, for me and my co-founder, it was just really fun. It was like maybe the most fun two weeks that I had companywise. Cuz the other part of the fundra that a lot of people miss out on when you're in a constant feeling of stress is you are talking to incredible human beings. Like these people have likely built incredible companies, built really strong teams. They're extremely smart people and I have a chance to spend 30 minutes sharing about my dream with them and then get their feedback on it and maybe get them excited and have a chance to work with them. That is really special. And the underlying thing what helped with all of this was just this deep feeling of gratitude that I had going in and coming out of every single call. And I think people can really feel that people can feel what your intentions are when you're coming into to talk to them. However, subconsciously so that way it ends up becoming a lot about the mindset. >> That's great perspective and I'm sure coming in with a positive attitude it translates in your passion about building something that you love. Adjacent to that, can you talk about building the team at Whisper? What qualities do you typically look in for an early teammates that have joined your team? >> This again may not apply to everybody. This is very much culture specific to what we care about. So number one thing is we have a very high ownership team. People have about two or three days to ramp up when they join the company and after that they are building, owning and leading their own features, products, sometimes even product lines. I don't care if this is a full-time person or an intern. They're all treated the exact same way. And that is great because we are able to attract incredibly high functioning people who don't like bureaucracy who don't like constantly being told what to do cuz we generally don't have that much time to tell people what all to do. There's so many problems that we need to solve and what I feel our job is like me and my co-founder Sahedge is to lay out the vision to lay out the road map give people enough clarity where they can make those decisions by themselves and then bring the best people in for the job so that we can fully trust them with it. And if you get people who can function that independently, honestly saves so much headache. You are happier, they're happier, and your company overall is much better cuz you just let people focus on where they work best in. >> That's good. People have autonomy. And what would you say are some of the core values or pieces of culture that you've tried to instill in your startup? >> Yeah, so there's four pillars that we build upon. Number one is open communication. That is I think how you build a high level of trust and I also think integrity is the only thing you have as a person that you can never lose and what goes with that is also just assuming the best intentions in other people. So that builds a warm culture. Number two is being user obsessed. Everything that we build is for the users. They are the eventual people that really matter at the end of the day. >> Mhm. >> Third is being very very very particular about the details. Every single pixel, every single millisecond of interaction matters to the user experience and people can feel that in ways they cannot express. That matters across all fronts. Um simple example that most people don't think about is for the emails that we send out. We have incredibly low unsubscribe rates because I go through every single word and it's like does this person care? Are we adding value to this person? Are they going to read it and think that it's spam? I want to make sure that we are being empathetic to what people are thinking about when they open this email. Why are they opening this email? What do they want to get out of it? Let's get them that. And then we have a couple of goals that we want to communicate. Let's make sure those happen as well. But at some point, if you stop empathizing with the users, you just lose that interest. And that just matters in every single touch point that you have. The last part I would say is a focus on growth. like we're solving a lot of hard problems going to keep coming up. Want people who take up challenges and when a new thing comes that they don't know about, they get excited to have the opportunity to learn a new thing. >> Speaking of new things, are there any upcoming features or developments you're particularly excited about? >> Oh, there's so many. So, we just launched Windows a week ago. We just launched the iOS app yesterday. And next up, what we have is some features that a lot of people have been requesting for. We are going to be dropping in the ability to have snippets. So if there's things that you send very frequently to people, could be an intro about yourself, your address, whatever, you can just add that into flow so you don't have to say the whole thing again all the time. >> There's another way where some people want to have more control over how their messages are sent. We're adding writing styles where people can go and and edit that and give some specific instructions on how they want their messages to be formatted so they don't have to kind of go past it into Chad GPD and ask Charad GPD to do those things for them again after that. >> That's awesome. I'm excited to try them out. And my last question before we go into rapid fire, what would you say has been the most memorable experience at Whisper so far? When we were doing the first launch, it was all of us in the office together for maybe 48 hours preparing everything for it. Everything was happening last minute, right? This is the first launch of us as a company. And then we launched on product hunt and then somebody had this idea of like every 100 upwards we do some challenge. every hour somebody's doing like we're all doing push-ups together. We're all doing pull-ups together and there's just like random faceoffs that are happening in the office. I think that was one of the times where where we all just really bonded together like going through a shared struggle as a team and that was special. >> That's awesome. And congrats on being number one product to twice I think on product hunt at least that I've seen. >> That's awesome. >> Shifting towards our rapid fire round. So my first question is what is your favorite AI tool that you use today apart from whisper? >> I love using superhuman. >> Okay, that's cool. What is your wildest bet about the tech industry in the next 10 to 15 years? >> Computer science is going to be useless as a degree. >> Oh, interesting. >> That's going to happen in the next five, not even the next 10. >> Mhm. I've heard this thought that it's more so that 10x engineers are going to become even more useful versus hiring people for like product and marketing. You might just hire an engineer who has a more business mindset to replace those functions. I feel like you're in the other camp though where you think that the engineers aren't needed and you can have like the marketing growth professionals use no code tools to code. Yeah, there was a time when you needed human calculators cuz no one could do that. Then everybody had a calculator in their hands that they could use to do whatever. And those humans were out of a job. >> That is literally what's happening where you or anybody else like our entire marketing and customer support team, no one's an engineer. They all have these tools. Instead of writing documents and support tickets, they just send us like, "Hey, I think we should build the feature this way." And they just send us the built feature. the engineers have to then properly build it into production. But the number of engineers we need is like it's not that high now and we're only going to get the best of the best. And if it's the biggest major in the world right now, one of the largest ones that is producing people, a lot of them are not going to get jobs. >> Interesting. And finally, what's the best career advice you've ever received? Best career advice that I've received is to genuinely care about people. And there are some very specific tactical things that go in this. For example, what I do when somebody new joins team is I want to understand what are the best ways in which this person learns. People learn in very different ways and I want to know that. And what are the best ways in which this person likes to get feedback? both positive and negative and knowing that I shouldn't apply the same model to every single person has I think been one of the biggest unlocks to the kind of manager that I am today. >> That's great. And I'm glad that you have that realization of getting to know your team better and coailing that your specific feedback and interaction style based on what their preferences are. I'm sure that'll go a long way. >> Mhm. >> But from my side, that's it. That's all the questions that I had for you. Thank you so much for joining and I hope you have a great rest of your day. >> Danica, pleasure is all mine. This was fantastic.

text:
Let's compare the top 3 most well known AI dictation tools & see how different they are from normal Apple speech to text. 

https://nicnewsletter.beehiiv.com - sign up to my newsletter for updates and rad stuff. 


00:00 Intro 
01:06 - Comparing the Free & Paid plans 
03:04 - Whispr Flow 
08:31 - SuperWhisper 
12:27 - Mac Whisper 
16:11 - Apple Speech to text
17:38 - Comparing email formats
20:03 - Outro

subtitles.srt: AI dictation tools could be the future of how we work and let me tell you why by incorporating AI into traditional speech to text software these new tools are able to use AI to understand exactly what you're trying to say and then format the text into your specific style for the exact application that you're using so in theory an email should be formatted differently than a text and a text should be formatted differently than a slack message and a slack message should be formatted differently than the instructions that you'd feed to a code editor like cursor and that's what these AI dictation tools claim to do if you're anything like me you probably tried the text to speech feature on your iPhone to do something like respond to a text while driving but when you look at what it actually writes after the fact you realize it got something wrong so you have to go in and manually edit it which defeats the entire purpose of using the text to speech feature in the first place but if one of these AI dictation tools could get it right the first time I could see how that would be useful so in today's video I thought it would be fun to compare the three most well-known AI dictation apps to see which one's the best and also compare them to the built-in Apple speech to text feature to see if they really make a difference okay so the three tools I'll be trying out today will be whisper flow super whisper and Mac whisper taking a look at the three different pricing plans I will be using only the free plans but the free plan for whisper flow gives you 2,000 words per week so that resets Weekly which is pretty nice but 2,000 words does go pretty quick so fair warrant there if you do want to upgrade it's $15 a month to be build monthly and you basically get unlimited words per week as well as a few other Pro features and then if you want to do it yearly you get it down to $12 per month now jumping over to Mac whisper Mac whisper you actually buy through a gum Road page which I find pretty interesting here so it feels very like Indie hacker but there are 169,000 downloads which is pretty crazy a lot of people use this but the Mac whisper starts with a free plan you can just download this and use it forever but if you upgrade for $49 one time you do get access to all their Pro features which lets you access llm models like Chach BT and Claude so basically accessing these more premium models so that your results are going to be a lot better now I'm only going to use the free plan which gives you access to one of their smaller models so might not be as good as their Pro Plan but that's what we're trying out today lastly we have super whisper and super whisper is free up to the first 15 minutes using all the pro features and the pro features get you unlimited use of cloud in local AI models like open AI anthropic basically gets you all the premium models and I will say again 15 minutes goes pretty quick so you'll probably burn through that within a couple days or hours depending on how much you use it but then if you upgrade to the monthly plan it's only $8.50 annual is 85 or lifetime is 250 so if you really like it it's probably worth upgrading here because that's a pretty good deal to have this forever you also get a student discount if you're a student but that doesn't apply to me now first let's jump into whisper flow and if we take a look at whisper Flow by far they definitely have the best UI so they have the best designers is what I imagine because it just looks sort of like a clean Mac app and it's really easy to use go through the settings and it's pretty intuitive to like figure out how all of it works so like you can change the hot Keys there's just not that many options it's basically like set it up once and go right you're not choosing from a bunch of different models or trying to set up a bunch of different settings it's basically like hey set your hotkeys and then get Off to the Races you text:
In this video, I am going to compare Wispr Flow vs SuperWhisper to see which voice dictation tool is better. If you're looking for an accurate and efficient voice-to-text tool, this review will break down the features, performance, and value of both Wispr Flow and SuperWhisper. Find out which tool works best for your needs.

subtitles.srt: Whisper flow versus super whisper view. Which voice dictation tool is better? Voice dictation tools are evolving fast and two names are leading the charge, Whisper Flow and Super Whisper. But which one actually delivers the best experience for creators, coders, and teams? Let's break it down. First up, Whisper Flow. This tool goes beyond transcription. It's built for intelligent dictation. You speak naturally and it format edits and even adjust tone automatically. Among its key features include AI enhanced cleanup and sentence restructuring, shared team dictionaries and reusable snippets, deep integration with IDE, Slack email and docs and hipa ready privacy mode with zero data retention. It's ideal for developers, writers, and remote teams who want speed and structure. Now let's look at Super Whisper. This tool focuses on real-time transcription with offline support. It's lightweight, fast, and great for capturing raw speech. Super Whisperer offers accent adaptive transcription in 100 languages, offline mode for privacy and portability, simple setup for Mac and iOS users, and a li lifetime license option for long-term use. It's perfect for students, journalists, and creators who want a no frills dictation tool. So, which tool wins? Whisper flow is the powerhouse for structured AI enhanced dictation. Super Whisper is the go-to for quick offline transcription. If you're building content or code, Go Whisper. If you're capturing a raw pitch on the fly, Super Whisper delivers.

subtitles.srt: Whisper Flow is ideal if you want fast AI powered voice typing that works across Mac, Windows, and iPhone with features like real-time formatting, voice commands, and multilingual support. It's great for productivity and team workflows, especially if you don't mind cloud-based processing. It starts free with unlimited use at $12 to $15 month, but does raise some privacy concerns for sensitive use cases. Super Whisper on the other hand is built for privacy first users who want offline transcription powered by Whisper AI. It runs locally on Mac OS. iOS offers clipboard integration, translation, and noise resistant accuracy even in tough audio environments. It's cheaper long-term with a $249 lifetime option, but is Mac only and may lack some polish for iOS users. Final thoughts, go with Whisper Flow if you need cross-platform flexibility, AI formatting, and cloud convenience. Choose Super Whisper if you're on Mac and prioritize offline privacy and raw accuracy.

title: Wispr Flow AI Review: Is It the Best Productivity Tool for Developers?
text:
Wispr Flow AI has transformed how I code and communicate. In this review, I break down whether this voice-to-text productivity tool is worth the investment for developers.

As a developer working in London, I've tested Whisper Flow extensively across coding in Cursor, writing documentation, messaging teammates, and prompting Claude. The results? A genuine boost in productivity that's hard to ignore.

Key Features Covered:
‚úÖ Three activation methods (click, hold, double-tap function key)
‚úÖ Automatic filler word removal (no more "ums" and "ahs")
‚úÖ Smart correction ("nine, no wait, ten" ‚Üí "ten")
‚úÖ Works globally across all Mac apps
‚úÖ Text snippets and shortcuts
‚úÖ Command Mode integration with Perplexity
‚úÖ Clipboard copy when no input field is active

The Honest Take:
While Cursor has voice input, I find Whisper Flow handles my New Zealand accent better and works universally across my entire system. The downside? Speaking to your laptop in public spaces can feel awkward, and at ¬£12-15/month, it's an investment.

Worth it for you? Try the 2-week free trial and see how much time you save. For me, it's been a game-changer for documentation, prompting AI, and quick team communication.

Pricing: ¬£12-15/month | Free Trial: 2 weeks

#productivitytools  #developertools  #voicetotext  #codingproductivity  #aitools  #macos  #developerproductivity  #techreview  #softwareengineering  #aiproductivitytools  #developerlife  #codingtools  #productivityhacks  #tech

subtitles.srt: I wanted to do a video review on Whisper Flow AI. Whisper flow AI is an app that basically takes your voice and changes it into text. Now it does that by basically imitating your keyboard, which is really awesome, and it can help you increase your productivity dramatically. There's a few ways you can trigger whisper flow. The first is you can click it. Now, when you click it, every time you talk, it will basically record what you have to say. When you finish, it will now paste that in as if that was your keyboard input. The next way to trigger it is by holding down the function key. When you hold down the function key after you release it, it will now do the same. The final way to trigger Whisper Flow is by double pressing the function key. Now whenever you speak, it will record. Then pressing the function key again, it will paste. So Whisper Flow will automatically remove unneeded words. So here's an instance of, um, whisper flow showing you, uh, that it removes unneeded words. It's removed all of my ums and ahs Another awesome feature is how you can say, let's schedule an appointment for nine. No, wait ten. If you have a look, it's just said ten instead of nine. Now, I want to show you a couple of the ways that I like to use Whisper Flow. The first is by using Claude to prompt. Can you help me with a YouTube video idea? Then I'll send that as a prompt. The other way I like to use it is by helping me write my documentation. So help me write a conference doc for our app that is calling a serverless architected TypeScript backend. And then from there I like to just prompt it and then edit it as I go. Another way I like to use it is through messaging. I'm not going to show you our messaging app, but I'll say something like, hey, that's been deployed, can you regression test it for me? Thanks. My awesome colleague who's a QA engineer showed me these snippets. They're basically shortcuts. So whenever we say bug report, it'll essentially paste out these words. So. Now, if we come to the page and say bug report, it'll paste out that snippet. A lot of my friends who are developers have showed me that cursor does have a voice input, which is true, but I find it really struggles with my New Zealand accent. The other thing I prefer about Whisper Flow is it isn't specific to an app. It's global on your Mac to any input, which is really great. Another cool thing about it being an app is if you actually talk without an input, it will copy to your clipboard, Another shortcut feature is called Command Mode. Now, if you query something like what is the weather like in London, it'll actually take that query and use it and put it into perplexity. So then now we can see what the weather is. I couldn't recommend Whisper Flow enough. It has truly increased my productivity dramatically. The only downside of Whisper Flow is if you do work in an environment or you are working from home. It is kind of weird to be speaking at your laptop and a lot of people do look at you funny. The pricing for flow is 12 to ¬£15 a month, which I can understand is expensive. For me personally, the amount of productivity it increases is worth it. But if you're on the fence, they do have a two week trial, which I'd recommend checking out. You may as well. It's free.

Which one deserves a spot in your productivity stack? Let's break it down. First up, Whisper Flow. It runs on Mac, Windows, and iOS, so it's got cross-platform fans covered. Honestly, I love how it handles contextaware transcription and real-time punctuation. You get transcripts that just make sense. No endless editing. Plus, it's packed with accessibility features, so it's a solid pick for everyone from busy professionals to content creators. There's a free version to test out, but power users will probably want to upgrade. Now, Super Whisper. This one's Makoas only, but what it lacks in platform support, it makes up for in accuracy. Seriously, it's next level, especially if you pick the Pro or UltraAI models. You don't even need an internet connection. It all happens offline, which gives it a huge advantage for privacy and onthe-go work. Integration with tools like Cursor is a big win for developers and writers who live in their IDE. So, which one's right for you? If you need something that works everywhere with smart formatting and accessibility baked in, Whisper Flow should be your go-to. But if you want top tier accuracy, fully offline transcription, and you're on a Mac, Super Whisper is tough to beat. No matter which you pick, both are leaps ahead of old school dictation. Try them out, see what fits your workflow, and watch your productivity soar. Thanks for tuning in. If you found this helpful, hit subscribe for more tech breakdowns and productivity tips.

title: Maximise Your Productivity with WisprFlow
text:
WisprFlow Review: My New Favourite Productivity Tool for Voice-to-Text
Discover WisprFlow, the productivity app that's revolutionising how I handle daily tasks! This voice-to-text tool has become indispensable in my workflow, and I upgraded to the paid version within my first week of using it.
What makes WisprFlow special:

Simple two-key activation (Control + Alt in my case)
Works seamlessly across applications - emails, notes, ChatGPT, and more
Intelligent formatting for lists and structured content
Custom dictionary for names and places
Free for your first 2000 words

Real examples from the video:

Drafting emails with automatic recipient recognition
Creating organized to-do lists with proper formatting
Taking quick notes that save directly to your apps
Research queries in ChatGPT and other AI tools

The app occasionally misses a recording, but the built-in history feature lets you easily retry. You can also add custom words to improve accuracy for specialized terms, place names, or people's names.

Get started: WisprFlow is free for the first 2000 words. If you use my referral link (https://wisprflow.ai/?referral=SEAMUS1), you'll get a $15 credit when you're ready to upgrade to the paid version.

Once you get used to it, you'll find yourself using WisprFlow constantly throughout your day. It's a genuine time-saver that I can't recommend highly enough!

title: Wispr Flow vs Aqua: Honest Review
text: Wispr Flow or Aqua ‚Äî which one actually delivers? ü§îüí¨ After trying both, here‚Äôs the no-fluff, honest comparison you need. From UI feels to smart automation, I‚Äôm breaking down which tool truly earns its spot in your workflow ‚öôÔ∏èüß†.

subtitles.srt: Whisperflow versus Aqua. Whisperflow positions itself as a highly visual AI argument task management tools that ideal for creators, knowledge workers, and teams who want a more fluid, creative workspace. Its strength lies in intuitive UI, modular blocks, and seamless integration of brainstorming with executive pipelines. Perfect for users who taggle between ideiation and delivery. In contrast, Aqua leans heavily towards structure automation and enterprise label escapability. It offers more robust role based triggers, cross app workflows and supports IT governance feature make it better fit for operations teams such as companies or even developers seeking custom workflows beyond basic task management where whisper flows shines in users experience and visual flexibility. Aqua compensate with deep automation versions control and IPI richness. From a pricing perspective, Aqua tends to be more expensive but justifiable. So for enterprise use cases, Whisper Flow meanwhile is competitively priced for solopreneurs and small teams. In today's saturated productivity market, Whisperflow and Aqua are two emerging platforms that aim to redefine how individuals teams manage their workflows, but they do so much fundamentally different philosophy. Whisperflow is designed with a modern creative in mind, blending task management and ideiation and realtime collaboration into a highly visual flexibility interface. It borrows designed elements from whiteboards, apps, flowcharts, and note takingaking tools like notions all wrapped into one slick experience. Its modular card system, AI assisted task suggestion, and intuitive drag and drop layout make it incredibly easy to use even users unfamiliar with traditional project management tools. It's cater well to content creators, marketing teams, freelancers, and even students who need to think visually and move seamlessly between task and brainstorming. By contrast, Aqua takes more structured enterprisegrade approach. It's a powerful house when it comes to automation, system integration, and operations management. Focusing on optimizing complex process rather than free form creativity, Aqua supports API integrations with CRM platforms, email pipelines, analytic tools, and internal dashboards, making it ideal for software teams. midsize businesses and operations management who need repeatable systems and conditional workflows that scale. Unlike whisper flow which is invites exploration and degree of controlled chaas aqua demands clarity each automation trigger and workflow is meant to serve masurable outcomes. Another big difference lies is customizations versus governance. Whisper flow is built for personalization. Users can choose themes, structure boards in unconventional ways and insert media, task, link or even creative assets directly into their workflow. You can go from writing a blog post to planning a launch sequence in canvas which is huge plus for solo users or startup teams. While Aqua however excels in governance security and reliability offering versions control, user permission layers, audit trails and error handling across largecale automations. This make Aqua better choice for high compliance environments or cross department system where accountability and consistency matter. In terms of performance, Whisper Flow feels lighter and more nibble. It opens fast, syncs instantly across devices, and doesn't overwhelm you with menus or tactical options. Aqua is heavier, more like a command center. And while that means a steeper learning curve, it also means far greater D and control. If you want to set up a multiple steps process that pulls data from Stripe, updates Google Sheets, sends conditional Slacks alerts, and then notifies your CRM. Aqua does that with procession. From a pricing standpoint, Whisper Flow is clearly aimed at the solo to small team segment, offering generous free tiers and affordable monthly upgrades. Aqualins enterprise often requiring demos annual contracts are highly upfront investment. But again it delivers on up time integrations and automateions power that justify its cost. Users community also reflect these differences. Whisperflow has an engaged user base made up of creative and builders sharing templates and aesthetic setups while Aqua forums and support channel are more technical focused on troubleshooting and workflow logic. In an honest sidebyside comparison, it boils down to this. If you are a creative professional, startup team or visual thinker who need allin-one space to ide executive without sacrificing beauty or flexibility then whisperflow is the more inspiring and enjoyable platform. But if you are managing scalable operations, automationheavy workflow or need deep integration with business tools, Aqua is more powerful, reliable and long-term solution. Each tools win its own arena and in many ways they don't complete, they complement choicing the right one depends not just on what you are building but how you think and work. inclusion. The choice between Whisper Flow and Aqua ultimately hinge on whether you are prioritizing creative edibility or systematic presence in your workflow. Whisper Pro feels like the natural extension of your thoughts, dynamic, open-ended and beautiful visual. It empowers users to think, plan, and act in the same space without rigged structure that often hinders creative momentum. It's perfect for content teams, entrepreneur, designers, and even educator who prefer free form expression blended with productivity. On the other hand, Aqua isn't about creative freedom. It's about creating order at scale. It's engineered for environments where process integrity, repeatability, and multi-layer automation are not negotiable. Aqua strength lies is transforming fragmented operations into cohesive pipelines enabling organization to scale without losing control. They both represent different ends of the productivity spectrum. Whisper float thrives in organized chaos while Aqua drives in or trusted procession. For higher breed dreams using both can even make sense. I date and map strategy is in whisper. Then deploying it operationally in Aqua. Either way both tools are excellent but for different minds, different missions and different measures of success. So that's it.

title: Processing WISPR 24 Mapper in Pix4Dmatic- Walkthrough
text:
This video is a walkthrough on how to process the WISPR 24 Mapper in Pix4Dmatic.

WISPR Systems: https://wisprsystems.com/

title: Mission Planning for Inertial Labs LiDAR using WISPR Ground Control (old)
text: How to plan missions using WISPR Ground Control with Inertial Labs LiDAR.

subtitles.srt: Mission planning with inertial Labs lidar using whisper Ground Control connect smart controller to mobile hotspot if maps are not pre-downloaded swipe down and click the Wi-Fi icon and connect to mobile hotspot then click the square and swipe right power on drone prior to opening whisper Ground Control open whisper Ground Control click the top left button to go to general settings select payload and then select recipe xt32 lidar you have the option to change manual or Mission flight speed change Mission flight speed to 5 meters per second for best results after completion click paper airplane button to return to in-flight screen click Mission planning button to begin planning mission set Waypoint altitude click take off button click pattern button click survey button click new basic pattern button play in polygon around survey area after polygon is planned select done with polygon you have the option to change your front and side overlap fifty percent front and side overlap are default slide the angle slider to rotate your flight line paths select terrain to enable terrain follow during your missions if needed click return button when you have finished Mission planning click upload required to send mission to drone click the button in the top left to return to the in-flight screen exit out of the start Mission slider to take off manually soft press button on lidar to power on unit and wait 30 seconds soft press button on lidar to start scanning and wait 30 seconds prior to taking off arm and takeoff drone manually and fly up to Mission altitude best practice to fly outside of mission path to start lidar calibration click lidar calibration button and Slide the slider to begin Slide the lidar calibration slider to begin calibration drone will run auto calibration and then begin Auto mission after landing remove plan from vehicle and close app soft press button on lidar to stop scanning and wait 30 seconds press and hold lidar button for 10 seconds to power off unit unplug battery from drone and you are complete

subtitles.srt: hey what's up fellow vapers what we have here is the ever-popular iolite whisperer now a lot of people have been saying hey you know what this is a great unit but it lacks temperature control well I've found a way around that and here's what you do when you initially fire up your unit you notice that the LED or the burner indicator lamp it stays on for several seconds longer you know on the initial startup because it's cold and then what will happen is it'll reach its temperature and periodically turn on and turn off the best way to hack this unit for a higher temperature is you start beating it up let it cycle you know four times provided that your indoor you know at about 70 degrees and then shut the unit off and then wait about two minutes and reignite the unit and what's gonna happen is your chamber is already warmed up but by shutting unit off and then reigniting it after about two minutes you're achieving a longer burn the heating chamber it's actually bringing the temperature up way higher they know fewer just initially left it on and let it cycle it worked great for me and I can guarantee you if you're a whisper owner and you've been unsatisfied with the vapor quality try this and I'll guarantee you you'll have a whole new respect for this

title: Wispr Flow
text:
Building Magic in Software. 

I sat down with Tanay Kothari the CEO and co-founder of Wispr Flow. Wispr Flow is effortless voice dictation setting out to eliminate the keyboard.

subtitles.srt: Well, hey everyone. This is the lowercase B podcast. Thanks for joining us today. Uh, today I had the pleasure of chatting with Tene Kotari, the CEO and co-founder of Whisper AI. TA, thanks for joining us. Thanks for having me here. This is fantastic. Thanks, man. When we were chatting last night, one of the things you talked you were talking about is, you know, you're trying to build magic. What does magic look like to you in software? Magic looks like it's the spark you see in somebody's eyes. It's the it's the slight smile that comes up when they're interacting with something that you've built. And there's one time when I was young with one of the first things that I'd built, which was a voice assistant. Uh this is back in 2010. I remember seeing that expression on people's faces when they used it for the first time. Uh, and I think I've never wanted anything else ever since then. Yeah. Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic. Yeah. I I had that moment when I when I used uh Whisper Flow and that was one of the reasons again why I reached out to you because it just seemed it seemed like from the outset you knew what you wanted to build. Yeah. Yeah. And you did a really good job of getting whatever you let out to to regular users, which is what I got my hands on was really good. I think part of it just comes from me personally having an extremely high bar for what I consider to be good. And so for the team inside the company, what that looks like is we just keep iterating and pushing the envelope until we get to some point where we say this is good enough for the world. And at that point it's it's something that creates the delight that feels so natural. So I was like, "Okay, I kind of need to take care of this thing myself cuz otherwise I get blocked very often." Yeah. Everything from a notification lingering for a second too long, a sound that wasn't perfectly timed when the action happened. A software that just made you feel a little off and that all built up. Never thought these two, like the design and the programming side of it would come this closely together, but it did in in a way with with Whisper uh that looking back it it makes sense, but they were just two separate tangents. I think that design is incredibly underrated both in software and in hardware. If you look at companies like Apple, Apple, what are they fantastic at? They make hardware that's beautiful. Yeah. It's just beautiful. And you don't even need to understand what beauty is, but you know, you want it in your hand. It's that magneticism that that gets you to come back and want to use it more. And I feel the same thing with with Whisper Flow. Like when I use it, I just feel like this is the natural thing to do. I want to do it more and more. Mhm. But what that kind of does for me is it builds a bit of a dependence on that tool. What what do you think about people becoming super dependent on your when you think about someone becoming very dependent on your tool? Yeah. Could you talk a bit about the trust of your users and how you you kind of uh embed that in the team and help them understand why you're building what you're building and why it's so important to maintain user trust? Yeah, I think this is something that I probably repeat to every new person who's joining and probably the entire team every single week about the fact that there are a lot of people for whom 90% of everything that they do on their computers is with whisper. Mhm. And this is a tool that is fundamentally driving a massive part of their life. And what that means is we can't we can't up. Like we have to maintain that really high bar for reliability, really high bar for user privacy, really high bar for the experience that we keep delivering to them cuz a really small thing like a hidden latency, losing something that somebody said creates such a big impact in them. And so inside the team, every single person is talking to our users on a weekly basis. I personally talk to 50 or 60 users every single week. And I want to talk to them and I want to I want to understand the pain that they that they feel. I think the one of the uh PMs at linear had a really good way to describe it where you keep asking the user question until the point you feel the level of pain that they do with the feature or the or the issue. And if you can build that across your team, then it gets to that level of empathy where uh you really understand the gravity of what you built. But you've picked an incredibly hard problem. In fact, you know, we talked about earlier, you're trying to convince users to break up with their keyboard. Why pick such a hard problem? I would say in some ways it's the hardest and also in some ways it's the easiest. You know a lot of people with whisper uh would ask us why don't we build text to speech inside whisper so that it can talk back to you and the and this is this comes up very often and a lot of people think that is the future of systems talking back to you and that is what it should really feel like. I think that's a very wrong assumption to make because it's not grounded in real hard facts, which is when you're consuming information, your eyes can do it so much faster than your ears even can. And when you're looking at consuming visual content, when you are talking about discovery, when you're talking about consuming a large volume of say like textual or structured information, your eyes are the best way to do that. So, we're not going to see displays die. That's why whenever I talk about it, I talk about going from uh display first to voice first interfaces. not completely killing the screens because they're very useful for certain set of tasks. And so here's the and if we if we're like drawing out this this world here like what you need is uh a voice interface cuz language is a common input modality. What you need is a display interface uh to be able to receive information in a very um high bandwidth fashion. And what you need is the ability to then also put in more non-verbal cues. And that could come from like facial micro expression, could also be gestures you make with your eyes and being able to capture that to do more uh spatial work overall. And those to me from first principles are like the three building blocks that you need. One incarnation of that is wearable glasses. 50% of the human population wears glasses, so it's not too far off from what people are used to. You have a display on them. You have the ability for them to capture audio really well, give audio back to you, and then some more sensing technology that lets you capture gestures, expressions, all of that. That to me is a full complete system. And I would say has I I would actually go as far to say I'm like extremely confident that that is what we're going to be using 5 years from now and you're going to see that have a huge explosion in the Silicon Valley first. Yeah. Uh as as we proceed and a few years after that in in the rest of the world it would start to get more common. In the same way we used to carry laptops with us everywhere. Then when phones came, you started leaving your laptop at home and carrying your phones around. Now when these would come, you would carry your phones around a lot lesser cuz you're going to be able to do almost everything you can do with these devices. This is going to be your your portable thing you carry everywhere. And you might just leave your phones at home and they may look different, be much bigger cuz you would primarily use it for more content consumption-y things. Like why else would you need a big screen? And that is just going to be a really really exciting leap forward. One piece of advice you would give yourself. Mhm. Before you started Whisper AI to not take things too seriously. I think life is life is stressful. Uh there's things that don't go your way every time. Mhm. Like every every day, multiple times a day. And as somebody who keeps striving for the best, that was something that I just didn't accept. And there was a there was a part of my younger self who was like, "No, I can I can make everything perfect and really strive towards that." But what ends up happening is you you try to spend a lot of your mental energy on that last like 5% that you don't have control over and that just shoots you in the foot. So that's been something that I've started to personally adopt a lot over the last year or so. Just makes me so much happier. There are things that are in your control. There are things that are not. And you just like shrug your shoulders and go to the next thing. And as you came to that sort of perspective, like how much of that was influenced by previous startups or previous companies you had worked at versus how much do you just figure out by being introspective and looking at the at the past objectively? So this specific one was just purely purely on whisper cuz um I think this was one where everything always moved for us as a really fast pace. And so in a single day I would be going from like extremely ecstatic to just like a terrible thing happens and then back and forth and back and forth every single hour. And there was just no way to sustain that level of emotional variation without needing to just have a different outlook on life. And I feel like that at least to like an emotional or mental degree, I wasn't challenged before this company. You seem like someone that loves challenges and that and once you find something you love, it's impossible to get you off of it. What advice would you give to aspiring founders or many of these new grads that might they might decide, hey, I I listened to TA and he told me that maybe now is the time. What what advice would you give them about just starting their own thing or embracing the uncertainty of building uh from nothing? I think there's a lot of people who think that that the job as a as a founder of your own company is is glorious. And I think like that's just what it looks like on the surface. what being a founder is about is like there's a lot of it where you are alone figuring things out by yourself. It's painful. You get the highest highs, the lowest lows and it really challenges you the most to an emotional and mental level. So that is something that you know the the way I always think about it is like everybody decides their own paths. I wouldn't say being a founder is the best idea for anybody like if this is right for you then you go do that. But the thing I do want to want to share with people like what it looks like to be on this side so that they can go make their own decisions uh for themselves. That is a conversation. I'd love to understand from your perspective like how would you describe the mission of Whisper AI to someone that's never heard of the company but but may be interested in knowing what you guys do. We are building the most effective way for people to communicate with other people and with technology. And if we succeed at that, I think that's a life well spent. When you succeed, when we succeed at that,
