subtitles.srt: Which one is the best Whisper Flow or Aqua Voice? Now, they are basically the same software. They are dictation tools that let you convert your audio or your speech into text and they position themselves as a tool to let you prompt with AI much much faster because instead of just typing manually, you can tell AI with your voice speaking and then it will produce the prompt that's accurate to your voice and it is being powered by AI and therefore it can fix any error or or any mistake that you say when you are speaking the words. So I think these tools are very very close. Whisper flow is already established and then we have a new contender called Aqua Voice and even though they are the same there are few differences. So one example here, Aqua Voice as a new player claims to be faster than Whisper Flow and they also claim to be much more accurate than Whisper Flow. Although uh the data is based on their own benchmark and I have seen many companies claiming that their product or their speech model is better than competitors. And I I can tell that this is definitely biased. This is not going to represent real life because there is no uh let's there are some models that are missing like there's no deep gram noa which I think is also one of the best speech model but it is not present here for some reason even though it has similar features to aqua voice and it actually they also claim to be the best at reducing error rate but again that's why I don't really trust the benchmark because it could be very different depending on the use case. Now enough about the differences. Let's talk about the what's the same about these tools. So number one, they both are AI powered dictation tools where they can fix the mistake on your voice. You can also see the historical data about the voice that have been converted into text. So if there is any content or any text that you don't want to say again, you can just check the historical data and just copy the text. And then there is custom dictionary. title: Corridor Scans with Inertial Labs LiDAR using WISPR Ground Control (old)
text: How to plan corridor scans with Inertial Labs LiDAR using WISPR Ground Control

subtitles.srt: Corridor scan with inertial Labs lidar using whisper Ground Control connect smart controller to mobile hotspot if maps are not pre-downloaded swipe down and click the Wi-Fi icon and connect to mobile hotspot then click the square and swipe right power on drone prior to opening whisper Ground Control open whisper Ground Control click the top left button to go to general settings select payload and then select recipe xt32 lidar you have the option to change manual or Mission flight speed change Mission flight speed to 5 meters per second for best results after completion click paper airplane button to return to in-flight screen click Mission planning button to begin planning mission set Waypoint altitude click take off button click pattern button click Corridor scan button click new basic pattern button plain polygon around survey area after polygon is planned select done with polygon select terrain to enable terrain follow during your missions if needed click return button when you have finished Mission planning click upload required to send mission to drone click the button in the top left to return to the in-flight screen exit out of the start Mission slider to take off manually soft press button on lidar to power on unit and wait 30 seconds soft press button on lidar to start scanning and wait 30 seconds prior to taking off arm and takeoff drone manually and fly up to Mission altitude best practice to fly outside of mission path to start lidar calibration click lidar calibration button and Slide the slider to begin Slide the lidar calibration slider to begin calibration drone will run auto calibration and then begin Auto mission after landing remove plan from vehicle and close app soft press button on lidar to stop scanning and wait 30 seconds press and hold lidar button for 10 seconds to power off unit unplug battery from drone and you are complete

subtitles.srt: Introducing the next evolution in enterprise drone platforms from Whisper Systems, the Skyscout 2 Plus series. Smart core power system that delivers clean power and shields against battery faults, ensuring maximum flight safety, 40minute maximum flight time, an average of 30 minutes flight time with payload. Path guard obstacle detection, long range front and rear sensors with 164 ft coverage that protect the aircraft from hazards during autonomous missions and manual flight. Terrain sense precision following advanced altitude control that delivers unmatched accuracy from low-level inspections to high altitude mapping where GPS and barometers can't keep up. Teg Guard climate control intelligent heating and cooling that regulates air flow to keep components at peak performance in extreme hot or cold environments. Signal shield EMI protection. Precision positioning, integrated RTK with end trip and serial pass through, plus PPK geo tagging through whisper cloud for survey grade accuracy on every mission. 50 mph wind rating to keep you in the air even when situations are not the best. Whisper Sky Boss controller smart RC with a 7 in ultra bright 2000nit display, dual roll wheels, hot swappable batteries, and 6 plus hours of runtime built for all day control. title: WISPR Smart Battery Firmware Update Guide
text:
This video is a walkthrough on how to update your WISPR Smart Batteries.

Download the update and update guide here: https://wisprsystems.atlassian.net/wi...
Link to Download Mission Planner:
https://ardupilot.org/planner/docs/mi...

subtitles.srt: Hey guys, Chris here from Whisper Systems. Today I'm going to be showing you how to update the firmware on your smart batteries. The first step is going to be connecting the adapter to the battery connector on the drone itself. And that'll just slide right on there like so. Once you have the adapter connected to the drone itself, you're just going to place the smart battery on top of that adapter. The next step is going to be connecting a USB from your laptop to the drone using the lower of the two ports. Next, open Mission Planner. If you don't have Mission Planner, there will be a download link in the description of this video. Once Mission Planner is open, you're going to want to go to this drop-own menu right here, select auto, and then click connect. Mission Planner will then pull the parameters from the drone. This will only take a few seconds. Once you're connected, you're going to want to navigate to setup in the top left. And then you're going to want to go to optional hardware. Then you'll want to go to drone canavan. And then you will select Mavink CAN 2 at the top. Once we're connected, we're going to want to find GBMS051601 and click menu and then go to parameters. And then we're going to want to change the parameters on system enable firmware updates from zero to one. And then we'll click write parameters. and click okay. And then we'll click okay one more time. Next, we're going to want to pay attention to that 119 right there. That's going to correlate to which file we're going to use to update each battery. It'll either be 118 or 119. We also want to pay attention to the firmware version. It'll change to 1.4.0 when we're done. And then we want to click menu and update. It's going to ask us if we want to search the internet. Click no. And then since this is CAN node 119, we are going to use the 119 file from the update folder. Click that and the update will begin. The first update is always going to fail. So we'll close that. And you'll notice a another node will pop up on the screen. We're going to go to the menu of that node. and click update. And then it'll ask us if we want to use the internet. Click no. And then once again, because the batteries node is 119, we'll use the 119 file. And this time, the update will proceed. The update will take anywhere from 15 to 20 seconds. Once the update is complete, you'll notice that the SW version next to the battery will change from 1.3.0 0 to 1.4.0. And now the update is complete. After you've completed updating the first battery, repeat the process on the second battery in the pair.

In this episode of "Run a Profitable Gym," Mike Warkentin sits down with gym owner Ryan Webb to explore how AI tools have transformed his gym‚Äôs operations‚Äîwith minimal investment of time or money.

Ryan shares his workflow for using Wispr Flow and ChatGPT to save hours each week on essential business tasks.

He explains how Wispr Flow transcribes and improves spoken thoughts, which ChatGPT can then turn into marketing copy, staff playbooks, sales scripts and much more.

These AI tools can even help gym owners navigate tough conversations with employees.

This episode will equip you with a complete system for quickly turning your thoughts into polished content that helps you grow your gym.

title: Wispr Flow vs SuperWhisper: Which Voice Dictation Tool Wins in 2025?
text:
In this video, we‚Äôll put Wispr Flow and SuperWhisper side by side to see which one comes out on top in 2025.

You‚Äôll learn:
How each tool performs on accuracy, speed, and clarity
Which one works better offline vs in the cloud
Differences in privacy, formatting, and ease of setup
Which tool is ideal depending on your workflow (casual use, professional, privacy-focused, etc.)

‚úÖ Like, comment, and subscribe for more AI dictation comparisons, tutorials, and tips!

subtitles.srt: Ever wish you could skip all the typing and just talk your way through emails, notes, or even code? Today, we're breaking down two tough voice dictation tools: Whisper Flow and Super Whisper. By the end, you'll know which one deserves your voice. First up, Whisper Flow. This tool is built for anyone who wants AI powered dictation that works across almost any app. Whether you are drafting an email in Gmail, coding in VS Code, or chatting on Slack, it's impressively fast, claiming speed up to four times quicker than typing. It also comes with smart extras like autoedits, tone adjustment, and support for more than 100 languages. Get unique lingo. It even lets you build a personal dictionary. Pricing starts with free plan that gives you 2,000 words per week, while the pro version at $12 per month unlocks unlimited words and advanced editing commands. On the downside, some users mention small glitches when integrating with certain systems, and the free tire can feel limiting for heavy users. Next, Super Whisper. This one's all about privacy and control. It runs completely offline, keeping everything on your device while still delivering accurate transcriptions with clean punctuation. It understands poses, corrections, and even several emotion tones. You would be walking, whispering, or renting half asleep. Whisper still catches it. This is where opinions split. Whisper flow uses semantic memory models which chunk your input into meaning clusters. It's great for brainstorming meeting notes and capturing train of thoughts idea. Super whisper takes a more editorial approach. It generates executive summaries, bullet insights and even meeting action plans using its contextual AI agent. Super whisper is more of collaborative intelligence tool. It links to Google Workspace, Slack, Trillo, Asana, and even Zoom. You can have it listen on the meeting and generate summaries in real time. Super Whisper uses tiered subscription model with free basic tier and AI enhanced pro and max plans. The pro tier gives you full AI summarization and advanced export options while Max gives you access to shared team spaces, long form voice retention and smart multispeaker separation. So whisper is ideal for solo thinkers and journaling minds while super whisper feels like an AI workplace assistant. We should also consider data ownership and privacy. Whisper flow is built around ondevice processing and end to end encryption. Your data stays with you. Super whisper stores transcript in the cloud and while it complies with major privacy regulations, it's less ideal for privacy purist or those dealing with confidential material. If you are working involve legal health or sensitive journalistic work, whisper may be safer. Next, let's go to the performance under stressed. Super whisper cuff multi segmentation labeled speakers correctly and offered readable result even without overlapping conversation. an incredible advantage for podcaster, interviewers, and meeting heavy user. It's like having a mini project manager in your ear. Whisper flow while more intuitive is less interactive. It waits, lessen and structures slightly. But sometimes the silence leads to better uninterrupted flow. Especially for writers, poet or creative avoiding distraction. Let's now look at how different user are adopting these tools into their daily routines. A freelancer screenwriter we interviewed described how she used whisper flow in early hours of the morning. Still groggy ideas flowing unfiltered, she speak softly into her phone, lets her thoughts unravel without judgment. And later when she fully awake, she copies the throw voice dump into her screenplays draft. She told us whisper isn't just a tool, it's my silent corriter when my conscious brain is still booting up. Ow. Contrast that with startup founder who swear by super whisper. His day is backtoback zoom meetings, pitch calls and team updates with super whisper running in background. He doesn't just get transcript. He gets task summaries, deadline pull into Asana and recap email sent out before the call even ends. To him, Super Whisper isn't just an assistant. It's business co-pilot. Whisper Flow believes is non intrusive clarity. It wants to be invisible, simless, and pure channel for inner thought. There's no AI talking back, no suggestions. Unlike ask if assumes you want to think deeply without algorithmic noise. Super whisper believes in proactive utility. It jumped in suggest summarize predict next steps. It assumes you want efficient oversolitude either is wrong but each appeals to very different headsp space. Another major factor is energy perversion. In cognitive science there's an concept called mental load drift where constant micro decisions wear you down. Whisper helps you drift inward. Super whisper helps you delegate outward. That's subtle but powerful distinction. Let's talk about export and final output. Writers love whisper row mood which outputs voice capture as untouched narrative strings perfect for creative drafts. Super Whisper meanwhile offers template exports, memos, project outline and even pitch decks. One user described it turning Kios into clarity on autopilot. Final verdec team leader, corporate worker, project manager or executive, Super Whisper is better tool. It's AI proactive, collaborative, and understands business context. It turns meetings into minutes and thoughts into task. But if you are a solute thinker, creative writer, deep worker or privacy conscious user, Whisper Flow gives you freedom. title: Wispr Flow raises $30M from Menlo Ventures for its AI-powered dictation app
text:
Startups developing voice AI technology and applications are having their moment. Model builders like ElevenLabs and Cartesia have raised millions of dollars in the last few months. Applications such as AI-powered notetaker Granola, and meeting tools Read AI and Fireflies AI have also received investor attention and backing. 


 


Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices (https://podcastchoices.com/adchoices)

subtitles.srt: [Music] This is TechCrunch. [Music] Startups developing voice AI technology and applications are having their moment. Model builders like 11 Labs and Carteesia have raised millions of dollars in the last few months. Applications such as AI powered notetaker granola and meaning tools read AI and Fireflies AI have also received investor attention and backing. Continuing the trend, dictation app Whisperer Flow announced today that it is raising $30 million in series A funding from Menllo Ventures with participation from NEA 8VC Opel CEO Kenneth Schlanker, Pinterest founder Evan Sharp, Carta CEO Henry Ward, and Lindy CEO Flo Crelli. Menllo Ventures Matt Craning, who will also back the company as an angel investor, will join its board. To date, the company has raised $56 million. The startup's founder and CEO, Tan Kotari, started building Whisper to create a device that would allow users to type just by mouthing words silently. Its prior funding was for that business. Last year, the company instead started focusing on Whisper Flow, the software interface designed for the hardware device. The company released a Mac app in October 2024, followed by a Windows app in March 2025 and an iOS app earlier this month. Kotari mentioned that since its early release, VCs in Silicon Valley have been using the product. I think every single tier 1 venture fund in the valley uses Whisper Flow for their emails, memos, documents, and more. They feel themselves being hooked on it, and it is one of the products they use every day. Because of this, we started getting a lot of inbound, Qotari said about investor interest. Notably, Granola also had a similar story of receiving immense investor interest because VCs use their product a lot. Qatari also noted that the startup will soon achieve profitability at the current rate of growth and initially he didn't want to raise money. However, he worried that big tech players with a massive distribution advantage could be a risk to the company. He wanted to rapidly multiply the company's revenue and reach and decided to take the investment. Menllo Venture CEO Matt Craning, who has been an avid user of the app, said that his initial thesis for whisperflow was that with the current set of input methods like keyboards, we are waiting for our thumbs to catch up with our thoughts. Whisper Flow is creating an efficient way to translate digital thoughts and intent. The app captures users speech and what they want to convey very well. The team has thought about how people speak while developing models rather than focusing on things like word error rates, he told Techrunch. The startup said that the app has been growing its user base by 50% month overmonth. Kotari noted that 40% of users of the app are in the US, 30% in Europe, and 30% in other parts of the world. In addition, more than 30% of the app's users are from a non-technical background. More and more people are using AI tools, but still there isn't a good interface for people who are not techies. ChatGBT style interface is the most common one and that was released 3 and 1/2 years ago. We are building for all kinds of users so they don't have to write system prompts to interface with AI. Qotari said at the moment, Whisper Flow supports dictation in 104 languages. Qotari said that 40% of dictations are in English and 60% of them are in the rest of the languages with Spanish, French, German, Dutch, Hindi and Mandarin being the top languages. The company will use the funding to grow its team of 18 with roles in engineering and go to market. It will also release an Android app and cater to enterprise users by setting up companywide phrase context and support teams. The startup is working on building flow into a product that is akin to an AI powered assistant that knows more about your personal context and helps you do everyday tasks like send messages, take notes, and set reminders. Plus, the company said it's working with some AI hardware partners, without naming them, to power the interaction layer.

title: VapiCon 2025: Voice AI Apps with Sam Spelsberg, Sahaj Garg, Michelle Lee, Jeffery Liu & Nick Ganju
text:
At VapiCon 2025, Vapi brought together founders from Delphi, Wispr Flow, Medra, Assort Health, and Zocdoc to discuss the realities of building and scaling voice AI in production. The panel explores critical technical challenges like end-of-turn detection and architecture decisions, strategies for building user trust in healthcare applications, and why domain-specific problems create stronger competitive moats than technology alone. These founders share candid lessons from handling millions of voice interactions across consumer apps, healthcare platforms, and robotics, revealing what actually works when voice AI meets the real world.

üí° Topics Covered:
End-of-turn detection as voice AI's hardest unsolved problem
Cascading vs. voice-to-voice architecture: why cascading still dominates
Latency requirements and optimizing for real-time voice interactions
Building trust and adoption: transparency over deception
Domain-specific moats: why hard problems create defensible businesses

üë• Speakers:
Sam Spelsberg - Co-founder & CTO,  Delphi
Sahaj Garg - Co-Founder & CTO, Wispr Flow
Michelle Lee - Founder & CEO, Medra
Jeffery Liu - Founder & Co-CEO, Assort Health
Nick Ganju - Founder & Chief AI Officer, Zocdoc
Bryan Parman (Moderator) - Head of GTM, Vapi

üìÖ Subscribe to our calendar to see upcoming events 
https://luma.com/vapi_events

üåê Our website 
https://vapi.ai

title: How Wispr Flow Uses AI to Save Professionals Hours Every Day
text:
Tanay's Bio:

Tanay Kothari is the cofounder and CEO of Wispr, the company behind an AI-powered voice dictation app called Flow. Prior to starting Wispr in 2021, Tanay has been a serial entrepreneur for 16 years since he taught himself how to code as a child. He has founded multiple companies, many of them focused on the next generation of personal computing after Tanay was inspired by the character J.A.R.V.I.S. in the movie Iron Man. He has also held product and engineering roles at Cerebra Technologies and Microsoft and served as a Computer Science teaching assistant at Stanford University.

Tanay's Links:

Website: https://wisprflow.ai/
LinkedIn: ¬†¬†/¬†tankots¬†¬†
X: https://x.com/tankots

Phil‚Äôs Links:

Website: https://www.philgcarter.com/
Substack: https://philgcarter.substack.com
LinkedIn: ¬†¬†/¬†philgcarter¬†¬†
X: https://x.com/philgcarter

Key Takeaways:

1.  Tanay Kothari and Sahaj Garg cofounded Wispr in 2021 with the vision of using a native voice interface to power the next generation of personal computing. Since then, the company iterated through seven other products before ultimately finding strong product/market fit with an AI-powered voice dictation app called Flow.
2.  The biggest thing Wispr Flow has done to differentiate its product vs. other voice dictation tools is tackle the upfront technical challenges that allow their product to work horizontally across any other single application. This year, Wispr Flow has been used successfully across over 25,000 different apps and websites.
3.  Unlike other voice dictation tools that transcribe what a user speaks verbatim, Wispr Flow waits until a user has finished talking and then transcribes a polished version based on what the user would want if they were writing. It uses context awareness to understand what type of message the user is writing (email, text message, etc.) and then makes formatting decisions based on that context.
4.  Two KPIs that Wispr Flow uses to measure product/market fit are zero edit rate and average time to send after completing a message. Wispr Flow‚Äôs zero edit rate is currently 81% and its average time to send is half a second, both of which are best-in-class vs. other voice dictation apps (including Apple and Google).
5.  Wispr Flow has early adopters across a broad range of users, including founders and business leaders, engineers, creative influencers, and senior citizens. Its horizontal use case and simple and intuitive interface have also driven viral word of mouth, allowing the company to rapidly expand across international borders.

Episode Highlights:

[00:00] Introduction
[03:22] Why Tanay and his cofounder started Wispr
[06:34] What differentiates Wispr Flow from other voice dictation tools
[09:46] Wispr Flow‚Äôs contrarian design decisions
[13:01] Technical challenges that Wispr Flow has needed to overcome
[15:26] How Wispr Flow uses context awareness to tailor its outputs
[17:50] Why Wispr Flow decided to launch across platforms sequentially
[21:12] How Apple has inspired Wispr‚Äôs company culture
[24:41] Who are Wispr Flow‚Äôs early adopters
[27:44] KPIs Wispr Flow uses to measure product/market fit
[30:17] The top apps that people are using Wispr Flow for
[32:48] When Wispr Flow knew that it had product/market fit
[37:15] How Wispr Flow generates virality through influencers
[40:47] Wispr Flow‚Äôs long-term growth strategy and team structure
[45:06] How Wispr Flow has approached international expansion
[46:00] Lightning round

You You'll be getting a customer support ticket from me later this afternoon. >> Um, how are you thinking about your medium to long-term growth strategy? Like, you you at this point, you've got product market fit. You're starting to see this exponential growth. the momentum is building, but but where do you think your growth will come from over the next two to three years? And then I'm always curious to ask, >> how are you structuring your go to market team to support that strategy? >> That is a phenomenal question. That's actually one of the key things that I've been thinking about a lot uh recently and there are there's two motions that I've broken it into. The first one is acquiring a lot of individual users and grabbing a lot of mind share. >> Mhm. And then there are a lot of kind of growth tactics to go and do that and very intentionally within the company every growth initiative is broken down into is this for awareness or is this for conversion. >> Yeah. >> Right. Because then that doesn't confuse those two things and just keeps the goals very clear. Um and the second part of it is okay we have an individual user on board and the unique thing about flow is it has really easy distribution within companies. So, how do we take that individual person and then upsell them into getting their entire company onto FL? And we did that recently with companies like Superhum and Substack and Mercury >> and a lot of law firms, a lot of other financial institutions and hundreds of other companies which has been been doing well. And so when I think about our growth motion, it's it's interesting. It's a combination of this B2C and B2B that we're running together. Culture- wise, I think the biggest thing that we wanted to set up from a B2C perspective is the is a norm of experiments and a norm of doing things fast. So, if if you're on my growth team, Phil and you come up with an idea like I think we should do this thing. >> Mhm. >> And it doesn't sound ridiculous, I want that to be done and shipped anywhere from between the next 1 to 5 days. >> Yep. I don't want to have any extended like back and forth of does this make sense? Can we do this any better? It's like no, ship it. Let's try it. We learn if we want to make it better. And the more we could do to support that velocity within the organization and make people very independent to be able to do that, I think the faster we move overall. And that's that's hard to have that mindset cuz sometimes people are afraid of making mistakes. Sometimes people are perfectionists and you want to get things done well like myself included. >> Yeah. >> And that has been one of the things that we're we're kind of like pushing forward as the mindset for every single person in the company to have is just ship it. And and this is interesting, right? Because you'll notice in the first part of the conversation I was talking about how we're very intentional and thoughtful about building products and everything >> and in growth it's different. And so what we essentially have to balance is the growth mindset of like the the shipping fast and encapsulated to a certain set of projects and the deeply thoughtful lots of iterations, perfection inside the product and have these two cultures exist side by side within the same company. >> Yeah, I'm so glad you brought that up because I was going to go back to that as well. It sounds like on core product you have a very high Steve Jobsian bar of what makes it out into the world, but on growth product it's the complete opposite. It's move fast and break things. It's let's throw stuff against the wall and see what sticks. And it reminds me so much of my time at Quizlet where >> um I came in as uh the first growth product leader. uh we had one product manager at the time working on growth and we expanded um the growth product team um into a much larger group of PMs, designers, engineers, but we had to very much instill this culture of the way you approach a problem as a growth PM or a growth engineer looks very different than how you would approach it on core product because a significant percentage of the experiments we run are going to be failures and then we're going to learn from our mistakes and move on. And the last thing we want to do is goldplate the code for >> an AB test that may not go anywhere. So, it is a different mindset. >> Um, last question before we get to our lightning round. So, you've already seen global adoption. More than 50% of your users are outside of the US. What's been your secret to expanding internationally so quickly or is it all just happened because people love the product and they're just talking about it across borders? >> Huge part of it is organically. The second part was unlike most other companies the first version of whisper flow that we launched worked across a 100 languages >> and so from day one we built it for international audience. Uh part of it also came because in our team of 16 people we speak a total of 30 languages >> which is 30 different languages which is wild and so >> the the team is very international and so that that culture just seeped into the product. It's it certainly helps when you're solving for your own need. And so if you have >> if you have the luxury of having a a early team that speaks that many different languages, then I could see how that would make things easier. >> Well, let's get to our lightning round. I want to ask you a series of rapidfire questions and you can just give me short responses. The first one I always like to ask is just what do you think is the best part about working at Whisper and what's one thing that you would change? >> I wish our team was in person. Our team is 30% remote and whenever they come into the office it is the most fun week and I just I just wish uh and and most people can't can't move because family reasons but I I wish they could. >> Yeah, that's something I hear from founders in particular and to me it's so emblematic of you have a lot of individual contributors who will say the opposite. It's such a relief to work remotely and it's so much easier to balance work and family, especially if you have kids. But as a founder or as a founding team, you know, this is this is one of your families, right? You're the company you're building is >> it very much feels like your work family. And I can totally relate to that. Like being together with your colleagues in the office, there's there's no feeling quite like it. And so, while there are many wonderful aspects of remote work, I can I can certainly understand where you're coming from. Um, what is the coolest AI app you're using right now that most people haven't heard of? >> I would say Sunno. >> I use it to make music and it is maybe the most underrated AI product of all time cuz I think video generation is just about getting to a point where it starts to feel real. Image generation questionable how good you think it is. But Sunno is incredible. >> So good. >> I'm going to have to try it. I've heard SUNO come up a couple times actually on this podcast because there are a lot of creative teams that are using Sono to apply music tracks to uh video ads, but I haven't used it myself. So, I'm going to have to go to try. >> It's great for that, but the songs I make, I listen to more than Spotify now. >> Oh, wow. >> I did not expect that to happen. >> Very cool. I'll have to give it a try. >> Um, if you could add one premium feature to Flow tomorrow, what would it be? >> I have so many. I have so many. Uh the biggest one would be for it to be able to do things for you and take actions on your behalf. >> So we've come full circle back to the agentic vision you had when you first founded Whisper because you said the first seven products that Whisper built were sort of agentic actionoriented products. flow is this voice dictation tool, but now you want to build on the foundation you've already built with voice dictation to be >> exactly because now you have the habit and now you can stack on a lot of things. Starting off with that would have been a mistake. >> Yeah, makes sense. Um, what do you think is the toughest user experience challenge for voice first apps over the next two to three years? I think we're going to see more and more of these products that are using voice as sort of the native interface of the product. But what do you think the UX challenges look like there? The biggest one that I'm starting to see happen, this is especially on Apple, is all of the privacy limitations and popups and restrictions that they are starting to put in. And that I think harms the user experience the most. That's one thing that I wish they would change. >> Yeah. Well, you certainly aren't the first to complain about Apple and their approach to privacy restriction. Last one. If you could go back, you mentioned that you started to code, I believe, when you were around 12 years old. So, if you could go back, what would you say to your 12-year-old self who was just learning to code for the first time about building technology products? >> Honestly, I think you did a fine job. If I if I changed anything about that, I wouldn't be where I am and I wouldn't be the person I am today. through all the struggles and all that I had to go through myself. All the apps that barely had any users that led to all the apps that had millions and I think that learning is a part of the process. So I would just I would just tell him to keep doing what he thought was the right thing to do and he'll figure it out. >> I love that. I mean it goes back to the growth mindset you talked about at the beginning of the episode and it's one thing to say you have a growth mindset but it's another thing to actually live it. And it sounds like uh you've been very authentic to that even even from the time you were you were just getting started as a young kid. Well, thank you so much tonight for coming on. This has been a really enjoyable discussion and I I've certainly learned more about about the product than I even knew even though I've been a user for a while now. Any parting words you want to give the audience before we wrap up here? >> I the biggest thing I'd say is we just raised a $30 million series A and now on track to grow faster and faster exponentially. And if you're somebody who's excited about growth, excited about building incredible products, especially ones that put smiles on people's faces day in day out, then drop me a note and I'd love to chat more. >> Well, you certainly have my vote of confidence. It's a great product and as a growth professional myself, I think it's a great company to be building your career. So, thanks again, TA. This has been a pleasure and um I I really appreciate your time today. >> Phil, this is fantastic. Thanks for having me.

The app is already gaining traction among top VCs, supports multiple languages, and has big plans for Android, enterprise features, and a full AI assistant experience.

Good question. Why dilute if you're almost profitable? You mentioned intent earlier. Exactly. They're working on building it into an AI powered assistant that knows more about your personal context. Personal context. What does that mean exactly? Imagine an AI that really understands your work, your communication style, your common context, your preferences. Okay? Interesting. So maybe licensing their software to hardware makers. Could be.
